review_text: A white family is vacationing in the Hamptons when the black owners of the home they are renting show up. Together the families must figure out what‚Äôs going on, because something terrible is clearly happening. This is an exceptional examination of race and class and family and what the world looks like when it‚Äôs ending‚Äînot at all different from the world we are in now. Finely o served details throughout.

This book is the most low-key and vague thriller I‚Äôve read and would therefore be best enjoyed by readers who like very scaled back horror that focuses less on action and more on subtle feelings of dread and uneasiness. The whole point of the book is that you don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going on, and it‚Äôs the absence of knowledge that is meant to play into the tension and fear. The story personally didn‚Äôt strike me the same way, perhaps due to the meandering nature of the conversations between the charact

4.5 stars

A middle-aged white couple and their two teenage children have their vacation at a luxurious, secluded Airbnb interrupted by a late night knock at the door. The black owners of the home are at the door with a story of a major unknown event that knocked out the power along the east coast.

Over the course of the next few days, tensions surface between the two families and fear is the overriding emotion. There is no cellphone, radio, or tv reception, leaving them totally cut off from the w

A potentially interesting scenario here, though one rather overplayed and everywhere due to Covid, but the writing had me grating my teeth right from the start: 'they huddled and inspected like Caravaggio's Thomas and friends', 'his penis jerked itself towards the sun, a yoga salutation, bouncing, then stiff at the house's allure' - the prose is constantly over-written with a 'why use one word when you could use fifty?' attitude.

The narrative stance is like a third-person stream of consciousnes

Prepare to be freaked the fuck out!!!

Amanda and Clay along with their two teenage children head out to a luxurious vacation home in the Hamptons. They spend the day lounging poolside, eating, drinking, and enjoying each others company which is easy to do when the wi-fi is so spotty where they are. After enjoying a nice dinner and after the kids have turned into bed Amanda and Clay just want to relax after a glorious summer day of sunshine but then there is a knock on the door. I don‚Äôt know how to talk about this book. It‚Äôs just so out of left field. I don‚Äôt even know if I liked it.

But I‚Äôll try to vaguely review it here, as just about everything that I want to say could be considered a spoiler. The biggest feeling I had while reading was one of tension. There‚Äôs something constantly bubbling underneath the surface and you‚Äôre never quite sure what it is. And that tension keeps building towards a climax, but it doesn‚Äôt ever seem to reach it. I‚Äôm left with more questions

Do you still have your bearings?

Two families forced to spend a weekend together....

The book begins as Amanda, Clay and their two children are staying at a luxurious Airbnb home on long island, expecting a quiet weekend away from the hustle and bustle of NYC. One night there is a knock on the door and there are the owners of the home, Ruth, and G.H., who have come to their rental home to escape the blackout in NYC. Soon the internet, electricity, and cable go out. Will no cell service, should Cla

This was a book I was very much looking forward to, considering all the positive hype it has received, and it's relevant subject matter, I could not wait to pick this one up. Unfortunately, this will go down as one of the biggest disappointments of 2020 for me in the book world... It just did not hit the mark . There was so much potential, and despite the explicit vulgarity and often annoying style, I thought it was still redeemable and could not wait to see how this came together at the end...

Going to have to mark this as a DNF for now, but I'm hoping that it will work well for me at a later date, as I've heard the conversations around race and privilege are thought provoking and timely. At the moment, I just can't slog through the over-written prose, but I'm hoping that the right reader will snatch this up at publication, as I believe in supporting this author and what Alam is trying to tell with this story. Basically, it's me and not the book. :(

I'm so torn over how I feel about this book. This definitely felt more literary fiction than thriller to me, which I wasn't expecting after reading the description of this book, I guess I was expecting something with a little more action in the story. But this book is definitely more of a slow burn, but there are some true moments of tension between these characters in this book that I really enjoyed. I listened to the audiobook for this one while reading along simultaneously, and I'm kind of gl

Well, this is definitely an original story. I‚Äôll give it that.

Amanda and Clay, and their two children, head to a remote area of Long Island to vacation at a beautiful Airbnb. After a day of of fun and sun, a knock at the front door takes them out of their reverie. On the other side of the door is George and his wife, Ruth. They are the owners of the home. After a sudden blackout in New York, they decided to travel to the remotely located home to figure out what is going on.

4.5 rounded up to 5

There's a lot of mystery around what this book is exactly about. Everyone is being deliberately vague and after having read it myself, I can now say that is the right approach. I finished this over the weekend and ever since then, I‚Äôve been trying to think of how many other books made me feel this way. Not many, that‚Äôs for sure. This is a book you have to deliberately read (and go blind into) and allow yourself to absorb carefully. I think one of the most genius things about i

There always seem to be books that get a tremendous amount of hype and critical buzz (and sometimes win major awards), yet when I read them I'm left scratching my head at what I might have missed. How could something appeal to so many and bypass me entirely?

Rumaan Alam's new novel, Leave the World Behind , is the latest to add to that list. It's a National Book Award nominee and it has been praised by numerous publications and critics. I have seen mixed reviews among friends of mine on Bookst

A white middle class family from Brooklyn goes to vacation on Long Island at a remote Airbnb.
Their stay is interrupted at midnight by an older Black couple knocking on the door claiming to be the owners of the house and asking to stay the night because there is a blackout in all of New York City, and they don‚Äôt want to stay in their apartment in the city.
So... they are all sheltering in place, getting to know each other while an unknown terror is happening

I thought I knew what a Rumaan Alam novel meant, but wow was I wrong. It is still so much of what I expected: the granular, sharp detail and the observations on a particular strain of comfortable, liberal white people. AND YET. I will not be the only one to have this experience, and in a way it's a sly bit of marketing to just talk about this like it's going to be a "strained relationships under pressure" novel of manners with some extra suspense kind of thing. For a reader like me, it is an abs

4.5, rounded up

Not a plain old thriller!

This book tricked me! Here I was reading a book about an apocalypse! This is NOT my genre! I went into it blind, like I love to do, and I thought I was getting a plain old thriller. But I don‚Äôt want to scare off people‚Äîthis is more like apocalypse light. There‚Äôs no gore, no dead bodies, no zombies. And there is distance (covering my mouth so I don‚Äôt say more). I think of it as a family drama with weird things happening.

I finished this one some time ago but hadn't found the words to really describe it. It's eery, bizarre, over-the-top crazy, and filled with numerous descriptions of awful body fluid functions; but I still kept turning every page waiting to see what how it would all be explained.

When Amanda and Clay and their teenage son and daughter head out to a remote corner of Long Island expecting a quiet reprieve from life in the city and a taste of the good life in the luxurious Airbnb they‚Äôve rented for

‚ÄúStep into our beautiful house and leave the world behind‚Äù.

A family vacation in Long Island is interrupted when the homeowners return with news of something weird going on. Is the world ending? Is there a war? A natural disaster? WHO KNOWS.
The synopsis interested me and I thought there would be some Jordan Peele vibes but wow, I was so wrong. In the second chapter we get two pages of what Amanda buys from the grocery store. That‚Äôs when I knew this book was not what I thought it would be. The ov

An interrupted vacation in a secluded area of Long Island, a possible national (or global) emergency, race, class, and family dynamics...obviously, Leave the World Behind is a very timely novel.

As Clay, Amanda, and their children, Archie and Rose, enjoy their time away from Brooklyn, they hear a random knock at their door late one night. Standing outside are the owners of the house, George and Ruth Washington, the elderly African-American couple who own the Airbnb home Clay and Amanda are r

My friends are all over the map when it comes to Leave the World Behind; I've seen every rating from 1 to 5 stars. Nothing makes me more curious than wildly varying reviews, which is why I'm more disappointed than usual to find that I come down right in the middle on this one.

On the one hand, the introvert in me loves nothing more than a small setting: Gather everyone together in an isolated house, and I'm a happy reader. Make it a fancy vacation home, and I'm even happier. (I laughed when I sa

The brain abets the eye; eventually your expectations of a thing supersede the thing itself.

Unfortunately, my high expectations for this book didn‚Äôt end up superseding my subpar experience with it. :(

But if there‚Äôs anything you should know before I get into things, it‚Äôs this: Rumaan Alam writes white people better than white people write white people.

Why I love it
by Siobhan Jones

Now here's a brilliant new book that is completely original yet somehow totally reflective of our current ominous times. Those who have read Rumaan Alam‚Äôs books are already familiar with his signature style: his wry commentary on small interpersonal moments, his masterful use of irony, the subtle plots. In this latest outing, Alam cranks the sense of foreboding into overdrive for an occasionally alarming, occasionally surreal take on family, race, and class that will

I feel a bit cheated by this book. I don‚Äôt mind mysteries being unexplained, and I don‚Äôt mind surreal moments. What I do mind is a chilly narrative voice that feels like it‚Äôs condescending to its characters, and is adept at manufacturing tension and menace and dread, but to no real end other than for their own sake. So this novel winds up, for me, feeling like a bit of a con job, in the end, and while I kept waiting for some authentic emotional life to bubble more convincingly to the surface, th

"Clay opened all the windows, banishing the stink of his farting children."

It‚Äôs generally a challenge for an author to win me over as a reader through the use of sardonic humor, but Rumaan Alam did a fair job of it here. Most reviews I've read so far for LEAVE THE WORLD BEHIND have focused on describing the story as suspenseful, but for me the novel dragged on that score, and was more interesting to me for the way the omniscient narrator makes ruthless fun of his characters on the way to telling

DNF @ 4%

This writing is insufferable. It's not even pretentious in a good way; I could appreciate purple prose! It's just! So bad! I couldn't even get through the first ten pages because I kept rolling my eyes.

‚ÄúThe air was that sweet cocktail of ocean breeze and happenstance.‚Äù

I started off reading this book in a power outage by candlelight on my Kindle, which felt like the most appropriate way of consuming it as I lived between the pages of its unsettling ambience with an expansively picturesque backdrop. I was ready to leave my own world behind and disappear into another, but this other world had stark similarities to my own in the way the pandemic has changed the way we think, act, and behave.

Thanks to NetGalley and the publisher of the book. Although the book is only 236 pages, it is still bloated. This should have been a 50-60 short story at most. The author constantly overwrites scenes that needn't be. It took 6 pages just for the couple to be invited into the house. The author goes on for one entire page listing food items that a character purchased. Is this really necessary? He describes scenes that have no bearing on the story whatsoever. These scenes could be totally deleted a

Leave the World Behind is one of my most anticipated reads of 2020. I've never read anything by Rumaan Alam before, but I've heard great things about his previous releases so I definitely was intrigued by this upcoming suspense/mystery novel.

Leave the World Behind takes place on Long Island and focuses on two families coping together during a time of crisis. When Amanda, her husband Clay, and their two children Archie and Rose go on a vacation out east on Long Island; the family is exci

I‚Äôll let you know up front that this review won‚Äôt do the book justice.

Leave the World Behind is a gripping work that deserves a15 to 20-page, organized, cohesive and astute analysis, one that demonstrates an adeptness at close reading and argues from a basic grasp of poststructuralism and critical race theory.

I‚Äôm not up to the task at the moment, unfortunately.

Right now, I‚Äôll simply remark that it functions as an extended metaphor for and argument concerning the current state of things, the

[3.5] This novel, about a family vacationing in a remote AirBnB house, is about fear of the unknown. Alam captures that experience very, very well. I expect I will remember this novel in my nightmares.

My problem with Leave the World Behind is that Amanda and Clay's responses feel like a case study. Alam examines them with a clinical detachment - describing their belongings and actions and motivations with effortful, overworked prose. Too often I was distracted from the flow of the novel by imagi
What the fuck did I pay money to read.

Did anyone else get A24 vibes from reading this? I definitely feel like they could make this a very artistic and visually pleasing movie if it gets adapted.

You know it's a little bit suspicious when Leave the World Behind is more unsettling than all of the horror books you've read this year. Unlike True Story, I do feel pretty confident labeling Leave The World Behind as genre-bending. Because I'm not sure what I read at all! Was it literary, horror, suspense, contemporary... not sure!

Probably t

A white family on vacation in a luxurious rented house on Long Island is surprised when an older African American couple comes to the door one night. The visitors claim to be the owners of the house and they are looking for refuge after a black out has struck the East Coast. There is no phone or internet service, but at least the electricity still works.

The blurb for this book says that the novel is ‚Äúkeenly attuned to the complexities of parenthood, race and class‚Äù. I suppose that the publisher

Amanda and Clay are vacationing in Long Island with their two teenage children, it‚Äôs a beautiful rented home, remote and isolated; a perfect escape from their normally busy lives in NYC. When the owners of the home, G.H. and Ruth arrive one night to tell them there‚Äôs a black-out in the city, and want to stay in their own home to ride it out, both couples learn there‚Äôs more to others than meets the eye.

LtWB is one of the most suspenseful engrossing audiobooks I‚Äôve listened to this year. The feeli

An interesting and provocative plot wasted over nonsensical, absurd writing. I could probably write a proper review, but I could also just copy-paste Merriam Webster‚Äôs definition of ‚Äúpretentious‚Äù and call it a day (fret not though, for I shall provide you with evidence further down):


1: characterized by pretension: such as
a: making usually unjustified or excessive claims (as of value or standing)

b: expressive of affected, unwarranted, or exaggerated importance, worth, or stature

- Very unique spins on tired tropes (end of the world)

- National Book Award finalists
- Descriptions of bodily fluids, sex and random nudity

- Pretentious prose
- Publishers Weekly starred reviews
- Very detailed lists that seem irrelevant but aren't

Skip this book if you like:
- Endings

Leave The World Behind follows this white middle class family that is vacationing at a remote Airbnb on Long Island. The family consists of Amanda, Clay and their teenage children. Amanda works in advertising and her husband Clay is an academic who writes for the NY Times. On the second night of their vacation, after putting the teens to sleep they hear a knock on the door, it is an

I was disappointed as this book was not for me. I would title it "Leave the Book Behind." I enjoyed the promised concept; the first few chapters and the last few chapters. Everything in between, in my opinion, was merely filler and the writing style didn't help.

It‚Äôs fitting I should start a book about a family going on vacation the moment my own embarks on a trip away from home. After all, regardless of what I am reading I‚Äôm constantly seeking relatability in some way, shape or form. Sometimes it‚Äôs a loose connection, if not a far-fetched one. Other times, such as the case with Leave the World Behind, Rumaan Alam‚Äôs National Book Award finalist, it‚Äôs a little more on the nose.

And by "a little more on the nose" I mean that on a surface level. For I was

**2.5 stars**

This is the perfect time to read a suspense about the world ending. I didn't get much suspense. This read more like a literary fiction.

I didn't love any of the characters, I didn't like that we never really know what is happening, and there were weird sentences throughout.

'He dipped a finger into his semen like a quill into ink. He wrote phantom letters on her belly.' Why?

This one just wasn't for me.

DNF 20% in. I like the plot/concept, but this book is so overwritten I just couldn't keep going. I love descriptive, metaphorical language as much as the next reader, but it needs to be sprinkled, not slathered. Here's an example of way too much of a good thing - a description of a drive through Long Island:
The towns were either blue collar and full of Central Americans or prosperous and populated by the white demimonde of plumbers and interior designers and real estate brokers. The actual rich

This novel had me at a blackout. An event that on a right (very wrong) scale can seem positively apocalyptic and a good apocalypse is fun to enjoy so long as it remains fictional. So that‚Äôs why I requested it on Netgalley, but then I forgot the plot summary by the time I went to read it. Often a good thing, but this time the novel had me seriously reconsidering selecting it for the first 11% or so, the three page grocery list alone was a perfect epitome of how much the writing didn‚Äôt work for me

3.5 stars ‚Äî The title is taken from the AirBNB description for a remote Long Island home chosen by Clay and Amanda, a white, middle-aged couple, for a much-needed family vacation with their two teenage kids. Their peaceful escape from hectic life in the city is disturbed by a sudden knock on the door late one night. On their doorstep is an older Black couple claiming to be the owners of the house where they're staying, seeking shelter and safety from a citywide blackout in Manhattan.

Now as a fr

I received a copy of this from Netgalley in exchange for a review.

It's difficult to spend time in the heads of parents Clay and Amanda, airbnb-ing in a fancy, isolated house in upstate New York with their two children; they're vapid, well-off white people, and when Ruth and G.H., the black couple who own the house, show up unexpectedly one night, they turn out to be reflexively racist as well. There's been a power outage in the city and Ruth and G.H. are weirded out by it enough that they've co

Couldn't stop reading this until very late, seeking plot resolution and exposition/explanation. Think of a treatment for a lesser late-season Black Mirror episode or straight-to-Netflix drama: a thriller setup with literary pretensions, building suspense through ambient anxiety with six people trapped together in a high-end Long Island AirBnB. Works best at illustrating the gradual descent of wealthy entitled New Yorkers into an (admirably) under-explained apocalypse that has ended technological

Leave the World Behind is a tense, riveting and claustrophobic exploration of privilege, race, class, fate, family, hatred and division and one of the starkest and most terrifyingly prescient stories I have read over the past few years. It's a deceptively simple tale but one that certainly succeeds at putting you on edge and getting both under your skin and into your psyche. It soon reveals its multilayered nature where, like a set of Russian Matryoshka dolls, each layer removed reveals another

When the world falls apart what do you do? How would you react? A tight intense story of a normal NYC family on vacation at a luxury house on Long Island when slowly they are forced to cope with usual events with no communication devices. Suddenly without internet, tv, radio or phone service they can only speculate. The Black couple who own the country house show up due to the city wide black out that mysteriously suddenly occurred in New York city and requests to stay in the in-law apartment do

God, this was awful! I normally would have steered clear of a massively hyped novel such as this, but I figured I would put in a library hold and give it a shot. My hold came in right after finishing Wolf Hall, and my brain was ready for a lighter, contemporary read. And to be fair, the first third of the story was decent. Yes, the writing is overstuffed and the sexual metaphors are truly jarring (I was reminded of Severance by Ling Ma, another book I wasn't a fan of), but I was getting into the

I started this 20 minutes ago, but it is either going to the trash, bonfire, or goodwill-I‚Äôll decide eventually.

It took 12 pages for me to decide to stop, that is a personal record. I really think the author needs to put down the thesaurus and use some short and simple prose to get to the point-and avoid the eye roll that I swear went to the back of my head . I‚Äôm just..... confused?

There is a very VERY specific audience for this book but it just isn't me! It is well written, I could see this turn in to a movie. It almost read like a screenplay. And there were eery moments that kept me turning the page. But the need to go into great detail about every bodily fluid/function and a very disappointing ending left me wishing I could get the hours I read this book back. Also the book was described as a book about race, but I didn't really see how that came into play other than on

(3.5 rounded up)
Seinfeld Meets Twilight Zone
Amanda, Clay, and their teenagers Archie and Rose are vacationing in an Airbnb home in a remote area in the Hampton, when late at night there is a knock on the door from the owners. They are older and in a panic as there is a blackout in Manhattan and they decided to leave and drive to their vacation rental home for shelter. At first Amanda and Clay are fearful that they were going to be kicked out. G. H. and Ruth assured them they weren‚Äôt going ask

A third of the way in, I had to force myself not to peek at reviews because the suspense was killing me. So many questions, so many puzzles. Mr. Alam has created an ingenious, spooky ‚Äúvacation‚Äù where 6 people are forced together due to unforeseen circumstances.

Short sentences and character studies are reminiscent of Agatha Christie, but the similarities end there. Freaky, unexplainable things start to occur, the physics of our world seems changed, and the character‚Äôs reactions to this crisis ar

You would think that in a world being devoured by a virus, with climate change looming over us, and the rise of nihilistic political forces presenting a bleak future, choosing to pick up another book about apocalyptic events is a bad idea. You would be wrong.

A young family rents a vacation home outside of New York only to have the home's owners show up the first night to let them know something has gone wrong in the city. The television signal is down, the internet silent, the two families not q
Trying to digest what I just read üòÇü§®üò±üòÖ

Asking critical questions about trust, family and power, Leave the World Behind is a masterclass in delayed tension, as two families seek to overcome their differences and survive what may be the end of days.

Amanda, Clay and their two teenage children have rented a remote vacation home in Long Island to escape the stresses of daily life. In the dead of night, the spell is broken by a knock at the door. It heralds the arrival of Ruth and G.H., an older Black couple who claim to own the property.

This is another that I may have rated higher if I was in a better mental space for it. Alam creates a sense of claustrophobic tension and impending doom that does not let up. The reader is dropped a few more hints about what is going on outside this vacation home, but for the most part, we experience the fear and and confusion right along with the families. The way that Alam addresses race and class issues, while important to the story, often feel clunky or obvious. There are also several oddly
I needed a palate cleanser, and this fit the bill.

Second, I want to try not to spoil any of the plot for anyone. Since I am torn, I think that's how I'll try to explain my review. These aren't 3 stars due to ambivalence, the 3 stars are because I loved some things and was disappointed by others.

I received a Book of the Month subscription for Christmas last year. I have dutifully chosen a title each month, no skips, gleeful in the idea that I will be reading something new and contemporary (I tend to read older books for the most part) and that others, hopefully others with taste, have culled what's on offer and presented me with only the best possible choices. This was one of those. It's my October book. I've made it a point not to read reviews about these choices, and sometimes not eve

I was not very happy with this book. The premise was very interesting, but the descriptions and the situations were coarse. It kept shocking me. The story didn't really develop or go anywhere. I'm not sure if he's expecting to write a book number two with the way it ended, but Im not sure if I'd give it another try.
Leave this Book Behind

This is another example of me falling for a hyped book. I hated this book! The writing style, the descriptions of sex and masturbation, the unanswered questions. No actual answer as to what caused the power outage and made the big noises. Why did teeth fall out??? Just vague discussion of government and planes? Come on .. I liked the concept of the terrifying unknown when the power goes out but the execution of the premise and reason for it .. just no!!

5+ out of 5.
Brilliant, like a meteor that might just incinerate us all. A white Brooklyn family of four rents an AirBnB out on Long Island for a week... only to have their vacation interrupted by the older Black couple who own the place, showing up and talking about some kind of blackout striking the whole East Coast. Tensions are simmering and like a frog in a pot, the heat keeps going up and it is hard to notice until the whole thing is boiling over -- and not the inter-couple dynamics, but t

Vacationing in the Hamptons is quite a sought after experience for many New Yorkers. This is what Clay and Amanda have in mind for themselves and their two children. Soon after the family arrives in their stunning rental, their summer plans of fishing, sunbathing, and relaxing quickly turn into a terrible nightmare. Alam has written a cautionary tale with its theme playing out like a Jordan Peele film. For those who enjoy Emily St. John Mandel. (Parallel foreboding emotions with our current pand

Errr, I can't be the only one who thought this was written in such an irritating way? I refuse to believe that lolz. Does there really need to be a metaphor for everything? And most of the metaphors aren't even good ones: I have receipts but I'll let it go. This book over-explains every action/thought these characters make/have. Damn, I get it. I get it already!! I assume it's meant to be cheeky or something, but enough already!! I thought it killed the pacing and unsettling vibe. It made me fru
Unsettling and unforgettable.

I am legitimately asking myself what in the hell did I just read. The writing of this book is incredible. As many others have noted, this book reads like a cinematic script. That being said, in terms of plot...I just don't even know what actually happened. I don't want to give anything away, but this just did not live up to the expectations that I had.

Thank you to Harper Audio for providing a review copy. This did not influence my review. All opinions are my own.
I could not stop reading this. A perfect mix of sharp observation, humor, and terror. Imagine the intersection of Reese Witherspoon and Don DeLillo. This is somewhere in that neighborhood.

Actual rating: 3.5 stars

There‚Äôs a lot in here about technological addiction, gender roles, and subconscious racism. It gets insanely bleak, but thankfully ended on a more hopeful note. It‚Äôs wild to think that the author didn‚Äôt actually write this in 2020. With that in mind, it‚Äôs hard not to view the novel as eerily prophetic. I could have lived without some of the descriptions of bodily functions, which just seemed crude, but the story itself was very compelling. And disturbing.

I regard this more magnetic and weirder than expected novel as a celebration of what literature is capable of: planting a seed on dry soil, watering it with creativity and inspiration, seeing it grow in the most free and even feral ways.

I had high hopes for this book.

What I liked

- isolated setting where anything could go down...

But nothing went down. At all.

What hurt this book

The Once and Future Witches is unapologetically feminist, chock-full-of-witches and sisterly: there's sapphic pining, books, reworked feminist fairytales and women in every form, fighting the patriarchy. It's not the writing - Alix Harrow writes gorgeous prose that is both smooth and chewy, rhythmic and immersive. But somehow, The Once and Future Witches ends up being less than the sum of its parts.

"Must a thing be bound and shelved in order to matter? Some stories were never written down. Some stories were passed by whisper and song, mother to daughter to sister."

Loved it! üß°üß°üß°

As I finish The Once and Future Witches, I find myself tucked in neatly in a circle of salt, not wanting to dare the world around it. With the scintillating aromas of woods and potions, enraptured in spells and bindings, I have found my calling long hidden in the folktales of my youth. Witches are real. They are still among us hidden in the codex of stories, humming their powers till the day for a reawakening marks their full return.

Harrow has done a marvelous job connecting fiction

'The wayward sisters, hand in hand,
Burned and bound, our stolen crown,
But what is lost that can't be found?'

The Once and Future Witches is a historical fantasy set in 1893, New Salem, where the ways of witching are near extinct thanks to the purging of magic in Old Salem in the 1600s. The novel follows three sisters: Beatrice Belladonna 'the wise sister, quiet and clever as an owl in the rafters', Agnes Amaranth 'the strong sister, steady as a stone and twice as hard' and James Jun

I was so excited to receive a copy of The Once and future witches by Alix E Harrow. After reading her first novel The Thousand Doors of January which blew my mind, I couldn‚Äôt wait to dive in.
It‚Äôs 1893 in New Salem North America there are three Eastwood sisters Agnes, Bella and James Juniper. They lived in a world that there once was witches but now is it forbidden. There tales and the spells are a now passed down from mother to daughter through fairy tales and books. It is also the time of the s

Witches, suffragettes, and Alix E. Harrow are all the ingredients needed for the fantastical feminist read we all deserve! And I guess all my wishes just came true, as I got approved for an arc of it!

‚ÄúThey keep burning us. We keep rising again.‚Äù

In 1893 witching is simply charms and spells made from nursery rhymes. Women are working in the factories and in their homes and some are fighting for their right to vote.
When the three Eastwood sisters - Bella, Agnes, and Juniper - are brought together in New Salem after seven years apart, they find the power they had only heard of in whispers and words passed down from mother to child. A tower appears in the town square - forgotten words have been s

This review can also be found on my blog The Tattooed Book Geek: https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress...

The Once and Future Witches sees the three Eastwood sisters, Agnes Amaranth, Beatrice Belladonna and James Juniper stitch together the wounds of the past, reconcile their fractured relationship, break the chains, cast off the shackles of servitude, rise up and readdress the balance of power, bring witchcraft back into the world and wage war on oppression taking up the fight for women‚Äôs and wi

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs all magic is, really: the space between what you have and what you need.‚Äù

We are all witches.

In The Once and Future Witches, Harrow argues that we have the means to tap into a reservoir of power to achieve wonderous and needful things. All that witchery requires are the words of execution, the ways of planning, and an unshakable will to bridge the gap between what you have and taking what you deserve.

Witchery has two histories. There are the centuries-old witch stories that have become c

The Once and Future Witches, Alix E. Harrow‚Äôs sophomore novel set in the late 1800s, is the story of three witch sisters fighting for the power to vote in an alternate history America during the suffrage movement and is very much a powerful and contemporary feminist fairytale. It is both a love letter to folkloric traditions and an ode to the fierce power rebellious women throughout history have wielded. There‚Äôs no such thing as witches, but there used to be. It used to be the air was so thick w

4.75 stars

Once and Future Witches feels like the book of my soul. This book captures that hidden wild spark inside all our souls that longs for otherness and power. The writing is so atmospheric and lyrical, it feels like having a cup of tea outside in the autumn in a garden full of herbs and falling leaves. The witchy aspexts of this book really spoke to me as well, I'm fascinated by the whole idea of crafting power from words and herbs and this book just felt so magical.

For the past two weeks, I‚Äôve been haunted by a lesbian ghost story, and I hope its ectoplasm hangs around for a long time.

This book left my brain buzzing so much it's hard to know where to start. Set in alternating timelines, this is, indeed a ‚Äòstory within a story within a story‚Äô. Beginning with the love story between two obsessed girls at The Brookhants School for Girls in 1902, Flo and Clara meet and form the Plain Bad Heroines Society over their shared love of Mary MacLane‚Äôs scandalous and shocking memoir. Sadly, they die tragically and Brookhants sees more tragic mysterious deaths until, ultimately, it closes. This opens the door for celebrated author Merrit Emmons to write a book a

This was such a strange and wonderful book. It just had so many elements that really worked for me. A bunch of sapphic characters, dark things happening at an all girls boarding school, storylines that play out in different timelines, a mix of horror and comedy, and a fun meta aspect. The story was so atmospheric, there were some genuinely creepy moments that made my skin crawl. And even though the tone would switch back and forth between gothic horror and meta comedy, it always felt organic. It

This was utterly lovely. It's a big book, but it doesn't necessarily feel like it is (although the story is layered and rich). Danforth created a set of interesting characters that felt very real and that I could sympathise with even at moments when I found them unlikeable (although Alex will always have my heart). Also, this book might very well be the queerest thing I have ever read, which in itself should be enough to recommend it.

PLAIN BAD HEROINES by Emily M. Danforth is everything I hoped it would be. I chipped away at it over a few days and it was glorious. I never wanted it to end.

1.5 stars!
This novel follows three storylines that are all connected to one place: the Brookhants School for Girls. Located off the coast of Rhode Island, it‚Äôs hauntingly beautiful and mysterious. In 1902, three of the students die after forming the ‚ÄúPlain Bad Heroines‚Äù society after they form friendships based around a book given to them by their headmistress. Fast forward to the future where a horror movie is being filmed on location about the three girls and their demise. Harper Harper, Audre

[4.25/5] Plain Bad Heroines flows back and forth between past and present. The past takes us to Brookhants School for Girls in the early 1900s, where two young girls mysteriously die and strange happenings continue to occur long after. In the present, we follow three modern women, all involved in the making of a movie covering the haunted history of Brookhants.

It‚Äôs important to note that this book is long: about 600 pages in total. When you first start reading, it takes a moment to settle into t

A creepy story so sweet that it leans into rot, as fallen apples bursting in the late summer heat. Like a songwriter, Danforth carefully chooses four or five notes to create terror, starts by playing only one or two at a time, and rearranges them into different melodies before reaching a caterwauling crescendo.

Memorable, complicated characters and a truly terrifying setting make this one that will stick with you.

This book had so much promise!! I really loved the premise, the characters, the theme and gothic vibe but it felt flat to me. The story jumps back and forth from past to present and both stories were so intriguing that I wanted more. This would have been better divided into 2 books. The writing and unique perspective is the reason I gave it 3 stars.

Plain Bad Heroines was such a unique book with a really great storyline. This book is a story within a story within a story lol. I loved peeling back the layers to this one and diving deep into this setting.

This was a fantastically fun book to read in New England in October, and it was, as promised, thoroughly gay, though it certainly wasn't as spooky as the press would lead you to believe. It's definitely got that pop-gothic sensibility that's so in right now, but the ghost story itself is pretty convoluted and ethereal; it's much more of a generalized aesthetic than an actual plot element. There's plenty of dread that doesn't really manifest into much of anything. I still had fun reading it, thou

Plain Bad Heroines is turn of the century queer boarding school horror and then some. It is not just a book within a book. It is a book about a book about a book. No wait. It's about a movie about a book within a book. And did I mention someone in the book is writing a book about the movie about a book about a book? Anyway, I think you get it. It's a complicated idea that doesn't feel complicated at all when you're reading it. It feels twisty and magical. And creepy! So creepy. I made the mistak

God I wanted to love this book. I was really intrigued in the premise and I was so excited to have this awesome story within a story all about gay women. What I got was 200 pages of nothing. It was such a slog to get through just those 200 pages that I just can't imagine continuing on. I really am interested in the past stories and the synopsis, but the book hasn't even gotten to the synopsis yet. The characters are fine, but nothing great, and the plot at the moment is almost nonexistent. Sorry

She is absolutely phenomenal and adds a sultry layer to the mysterious happenings at Brookhants that I definitely wouldn't have felt if I read it myself.

There are A TON of characters and learning their names and what timeline they're in is kind of confus

this hits some really good notes -- swarming insects ! rotting fruit ! boarding school ! oppressive atmospheres, and eyes everywhere ! lesbianism ! truly visceral mouth-horror ! increasingly slippery realities ! the also slippery nature of story-making & story-telling !

i didn't always like the book on a technical level -- i found the narrative voice a little grating & the pacing uneven? the book as a whole felt a little messy, stretched pretty thin in places, snapping too tight, skipping over t

I could see this working brilliantly for another reader, but for me I'm just going to have to set it aside.

Well-written and intricately plotted, this book, through no fault of it's own, buzzes a few of my pet peeves right off the bat - multiple POVs and long-(long, long)-game plots. I really only feel invested in the three present-day girls, and the overarching sense of dread on their behalf makes it really hard to pick up the book.

I'm also not really finding that there's a good balance between

This gothic tale is not a book you want to enter into lightly. Make sure your schedule is clear and you will want to give your full attention to Plain Bad Heroines by Emily M. Danforth. I thoroughly enjoyed it, but I really did need to concentrate. There were footnotes, sly comments, and metafiction to keep your mind engaged. And the gorgeous illustrations throughout by Sara Lautman added another wonderful element to Plain Bad Heroines.

This was a slow read for me, but the story pace wasn‚Äôt slow.

Plain Bad Heroines is capital-G Gothic with some good spooky vibes. The narration is cool, and the actual craft of the novel is interesting. I'm definitely questioning some of the choices that were made, though. The structure wasn't always totally effective, and did that many queer women have to die in one book? Still, I think plenty of readers will enjoy this book.

I attended a small women's college that had plenty of ghost stories as part of campus l

This book has everything I don't usually like: it's long, the audiobook narrator sings, it flips between past and present, it's horror, and I didn't trust that it wouldn't be too YA despite the marketing (it has illustrations, for crying out loud). But none of that mattered (and it turned out the "not YA" promise was fulfilled). I wouldn't say the book won me over, because it started strong and just kept going. And for a 600 page book, it really didn't feel padded or overlong. It actually never

This book isn't for everyone, but it was perfect for me! This is the EXACT type of book I was wanting to read this October--spooky, atmospheric, dark, and chilling. An elaborate, dual timeline story that transcended the page. Everything came to life and it was just so much fun. The conclusion felt a little rushed and anticlimactic for me, which is why I docked 1/4 star. The rest of the book is well worth the high rating. Loved!

4.75

OMG so good. This is a long ass book to really sink your teeth into - a creepy, queer, absorbing metafiction about a haunted boarding school. Dual narratives - one in the early 1900s at the Rhode Island boarding school and one in modern day Hollywood - weave in and out, piecing together a creepy story of forbidden love, unjust consequences, and strong ladies getting revenge. This was a book I didn't want to end (and that's saying a lot because I love finishing books).

Do you like books about cursed boarding schools? Gothic? Giant? Funny? Queer positive? Meta? Ultra ooky spooky? Blurbed by Sarah Waters?
Then, you should most definitely read this book when it comes out. I loved this book! It has absolutely everything in it.

An incredibly satisfying book, hitting many of my wheelhouses. Part historical novel, part contemporary filmmaking novel, and all LGBTQ fiction. Both narratives were engrossing and fed off each other well, telling parallel tales of the lives of queer women at the beginning of the 20th century and today. It had just enough ghost story, just enough Rhode Island history, just enough Hollywood-life, and very enjoyable footnotes! Highly recommended. Thanks to NetGalley and the publisher for a free co

They also fall in love, only to die tragically in each other's arms, while fighting off a swarm of yellow jackets. Mary MacLane's diary is found near their bodies.

Fun and sprawling and creepy and meta. Just a delightful long read.

Black Sun is the first instalment in the Between Earth and Sky series, a high fantasy inspired by pre-columbian americas. We follow multiple perspectives from all across this vibrant world, all seemingly separate at the beginning, but soon become entangled with one another's story. Exceptional!

The Hollow Places is a thoroughly entertaining novel that plays around with parallel worlds, portal fantasy and cosmic horror. When our narrator, Kara, moves back to her hometown (Hog Chapel, North Carolina) she is still reeling from her divorce. To avoid sharing a house with her mother she volunteers to work in her uncle's peculiar museum (Glory to God Museum of Natural Wonders, Curiosity, and Taxidermy). She decides to catalogue the many curios and bizarre objects that live there. A

"Does your uncle know there's a portal to Narnia in his museum?"

This was a surprise. I've read books before that I started and the novel was not anything like I expected it to be from the description. Sometimes that's disappointing and other times it works out better. In this case, I think this is a much better book than I expected it to be.

The Hollow Places is the latest supernatural horror novel from the inimitable Ursula Vernon, under the nom de plume T. Kingfisher. Newly divorced and perturbed by the prospect of having to move back in with her parents, 34-year-old graphic artist Kara (aka Carrot) returns to where she spent her formative years, picturesque Hog Chapel, North Carolina, and gladly accepts her eccentric Uncle Earl‚Äôs offer of inhabiting a spare room in Glory to God Museum of Natural Wonders, Curiosities and Taxidermy

THE HOLLOW PLACES BY: T. KINGFISHER I think this book will stay with me for awhile, I'm afraid the willows have taken root. I know many people draw the obvious parallels with Lovecraft, but for me this one also had some vibes that brought up touchstones from The Mist (Stephen King) and a smidge of Pan's Labyrinth. Definitely that dark otherworldliness but also the religious and/or mythical undertones throughout.
 
Sometimes the vastness and imagination that goes into multiverses can be overwhelmin

The story itself is smaller and more contained with only three main characters, but what the two of them discover hiding behind the wall of the third‚Äôs place of business is pretty epic. Recently divorced, living back home with her parents, and working at her uncle's glorified curiosity shop - the Wonder Museum - nothing much seems like it would shake up Kara, our unflappable narrator. After her marriage ends in divorce, Kara moves into her uncle's museum of oddities and antiquities. From the start, P. Djeli Clark's RING SHOUT explodes into vivid color with a voice that's at once joyous and harrowing. Maryse is a stunning character, real and layered, and brilliantly employed in a novella that is confident, razor sharp, and utterly imaginative. An instant favorite.

Ring Shout is a weird and smart little novella that blurs the lines between historical fantasy and horror. It follows a group of Black women in the 1920's who hunt evil KKK members, but with a twist. This is a fascinating story that serves to frame very real history through a fantastical lens that perhaps allows for a different approach to insight. It has impressively deep worldbuilding and well-developed characters despite the length.

I have had P. Djeli Clark on my radar for a while now, with him releasing various novellas through Tor.com. After reading the premise of this one, I had to give it a whirl. He knocked it out of the park.

Thanks to NetGalley for this audiobook. The narrator of this dark fantasy was incredible. The story is character driven and I loved Maryse and her magic sword. Sadie was an extremely likeable character.

This is a story about monsters. Otherworldly beings and those who walk amongst us. The Klu Kluxes are pure hatred and evil personified as shape shifting monsters - and only a small band of female warriors can see them for what they really are.

This is a tale of vengeance and injustice, gore and terror and ultimately love and hope. I loved reading about Maryse and her band of strong women, and really enjoyed how African myth and history was incorporated into this story. It was a great adventure.

RING SHOUT by P. Dj√®l√≠ Clark is one of the best books of 2020. It is so unique and downright spectacular. Tor continues to impress me with their novellas.

The story takes place in Macon, Georgia, during the 1920s Prohibition. G.W. Griffith releases a film called Birth of a Nation, and when Ku Klux Klan members view it, they become evil demons called Ku Kluxes. From Dead Djinn, to Tram Car 015, and now Ring Shout, Clark manages to make his worlds as familiar as they are rich and vividly imaginative. His settings become places I've been before. His characters are people I know. His magic is something I've witnessed or wielded in tangible memories. RING SHOUT is no different. Here, he's found the only way to write about the Klan that doesn't give me violent, ancestral fits. A feat, all things considered.

I've said it once and I'll say it again: P. Dj√®l√≠ Clark is one of the best SFF writers out there right now. He is a master of plot, and worldbuilding, often creating whole universes in a short story or novella. Clark also gives us the stories and characters we've longed to see in SFF for so long: from Egyptian detectives in A Dead Djinn in Cairo to Orisha-possessed heroines in The Black God's Drums. He does it yet again in

The novella perfectly captures the inner voice of a young southern black woman living in 1922 with its rhythm and slang. The informal writing style allowed me to get a real sense of the main character's personality.

The protagonist is a demon hunter who slays Ku Kluxes, monsters who are born from hate. She wields a sword whose powers comes from the misery of past slaves. The descriptions of the monsters were gruesome and horrifying! A white tree with a fleshy interior. A body covered with mouths

This has a lot of what I love about Clark‚Äôs work but is definitely a new and different direction. The wonderful characters are there and the rich and fully developed world is also there, but it is more weird and serious and less charming than his other work. Not worse. Just different. Recommended for people who liked The City We Became, Riot Baby, or any of Victor Lavalle.

This book is written so tightly it feels as if not a single word is wasted. Maryse takes us on a journey to the south and along the way teaches us the folk tales that give her power. This story is about the power of hate in a fantastical world that looks like our own USA. The hate in our world is real and this book can teach us something about how to fight it.

Excellent. Strong depth of character and world building within a shorter novella format. Really enjoy books that don't cater to a white audience and just says here is the world, sink or swim. The use of Gullah without providing translations or, in a lot of cases even supporting contextual dialogue, is just brilliant.

This is not only the author's best work to date, but an agonisingly timely and heart-wrenching story of resistance, horror, and hope. Full review to follow closer to publication (October) on https://fantasy-hive.co.uk/.

A dark fantasy read with current social commentary. Taking place in Macon, Georgia during the Prohibition Era. Ku Klux Klan members see a movie called Birth of a nation, they become evil demons called Ku Kluxes. Maryse Boudreaux and her resistance fighters, Sadie and Chef are sent to kill the Ku Kluxes to save the world. It has action, suspense, historical fiction and horror. It‚Äôs a novella that packs an impactful punch.

Okay, truly, ANYTHING written by Clark is frikkin amazing (I believe I have, in the past, waxed poetic about both The Black God's Drums and The Haunting of Tram Car 015) but, Ring Shout is something completely different. Maryse, a woman with a lot of anger, a lot of love, and a magic sword, has to face the demons created by hatred--not just external demons, but the ones in her head, too. Ring Shout is a stark, perfectly blunt piece of speculative fiction that is sure to make you shudder and *gasp* from all of the body horror while drawing you into the magical and fantastically weaved world by Clark. Clark completely masters taking a moment in time, and sculpting it into something so unbelievably real that it is horrifying- and you don‚Äôt want to look away. Expertly mixing unnerving fiction with true historical events and timelines, Clark delivers a gut punch in under 200 pages. I

Ring Shout is an experience. It reads like a surreal fever dream in some parts and alternative history all at once. With elements of horror, dark fantasy, and history, Clark insures that readers of all kinds will enjoy this read.

Once again P. Dj√®l√≠ Clark delivers a masterpiece work of fiction! I don't know how this man can pack so much emotion, beauty, sadness, character development, awesome characters, actions into a short novel, but by all that is holy in this world he does it and does it brilliantly.

To justify how movements of hate in human history can involve so many people, a label of 'monstrosity' is often attributed to their nature--and in Ring Shout, P. Dj√®l√≠ Clark makes that monstrosity literal in a fantastical setting of a post-world-war Southern United States, where senseless hate invokes the attention of the purest evil, and connections to ancestral roots manifest in magic and spiritual power.

In the vein of Matt Ruff‚Äôs Lovecraft Country, which I also read this year and loved, Clark‚Äôs book expertly melds Lovecraftian horror with the everyday horror of history. As the book begins, it‚Äôs only about a year out from the Tulsa Massacre, which you may have seen depicted on Watchmen. If you didn‚Äôt, then the briefest explanation is that a group flattened Tulsa‚Äôs prosperous Black community basically because they could.

[4.25/5] I was initially attracted to The Cold Millions by Jess Walter because it‚Äôs set mostly in Spokane, and I‚Äôm from the Pacific Northwest. But when I saw it was set in the early 1900s during the time of labor rights protests and suffragists, I was even more intrigued!

Whoa! I thought I would like this novel set in Spokane, WA, at the turn of the last century, but I wasn't expected to be blown away.

At the core of the book is the story of two brothers who arrive in Spokane looking for seasonal work and who get caught up in the free speech movement and union organizing. Interspersed are short vignettes, told in the first person, that provide the backgrounds and ultimate fates of key characters (at least two of which are historic figures).

I was thoroughly investe
PW Best of 2020

Two brothers, 16 and 23, have no home so they head west arriving in Spokane in time for the 1909 riots. Union organizers are denied the freedom to protest and speak publicly. Police brutality puts one brother in jail while the other goes with a union organizer to raise money. The novel is a real page turner and certainly timely. The author of BEAUTIFUL RUINS has succeeded with an entirely different sort of novel.

The book covered a topic that I know very little about; the union struggles in the Northwest in the early 2oth century. The relationship between Rye and Gig is interesting. Throughout the book you see Rye, the younger brother, play the protector role for his older brother, Gig. Overall I liked it and would be interested in reading other books by Jess Walter.

Jess Walter is a wonder. I read and loved Beautiful Ruins. The Cold Millions is an altogether completely different story with a completely different feel, and I loved this one, too. It is the story of brothers Gregory and Ryan Dolan, two hobos trying to survive in 1909 Spokane, Washington. This is the time of the "Wobblies" - or the IWW - the labor union called the Industrial Workers of the World, laborers trying to stand up for

A novel which tells the story of the International Workers of the World, or IWW‚Äîalso known as the Wobblies‚Äîbeginning their fight for free speech . . . as defined by the right to  meet, solicit, form and ultimately organize a union . . . among the laborers of the timber and mining companies who were so prolific in the area at that time. Rye Nolan is the main focus, a young teenager who goes on the hobo road after his parents and other siblings died. He finds his brother Gig (Gregory) and they tramp around until settling for a while in Spokane, WA sleeping on the porch of an old Italian woman, who promised they could buy her backyard orchard land to build their own house. This is historical fiction at its best. Many of the characters were actual people experiencing actual events that are dramatized in this novel. The main female character led such an amazing life that her story would make this book worth reading just for that. But there is so much more. I didn't find any of the characters stereotyped though it would have been an easy trap to fall into when writing of the beginnings of union organizing in the early 1900s in Spokane, Seattle, Missoula, and Butte. G

Walter packs this book with so much historical and sensory detail, and then grounds all that detail in incredibly compelling characters. Part of that entailed weaving various viewpoints into the narrative, so even though it is very much Rye‚Äôs story, the reader gets to sit in on all these other experiences and perspectives. Spokane in 1909 came so vividly to life for me, as did the issues of the era. And, of course, the issues raised are things that are strongly echoed in our society now. This wa

"Rye began to see that he was living in a particular moment in history." -Rye Dolan. While this book takes place at a particular moment in history I cannot deny it is a story about any time, any place that injustice is occuring. I would die for Rye and the supporting characters are so well fleshed out.

This rollicking novel set in the Northwest revives one of the most interesting historical eras I know -- that of early labor strife, particularly the Free Speech demonstrations staged by the One Big Union, the IWW, the romantically infamous Wobblies.

This is author Jess Walter's history of Spokane, Washington's anti-Union past. It's 1910, and two brothers on the bum meet up with a Wobbly led free-speech movement in Spokane. The orphan brothers Gig and Rye get involved in the union, the prisons, the law, the hoboes, and the rich elite of the town. This is one of those big Great American novel moments- the story of a mostly forgotten time and place and events brought to life by a skilled storyteller and humanized with memorable characters. The fight of the IWW (the Wobblies) for free speech in Spokane in 1909 would not, on its face, seem to ba an appealing topic. The fate of Gig and Rye, young poor brothers caught up in it, is. Jess Walter mixes real people with fictional characters in his historical fiction about the early 20th century labor wars in and around Spokane, Washington. He stresses in an afterword that the representations of real people are his fictional representations, although he strives to hew closely to major events.

A terrific fictional account of the labor strike in early 20th C Spokane. I knew nothing of the event, so it was an additional pleasure to find oneself inside the early fights of labor, in this case the IWW known as the Wobblies. It was a fight not for the fainthearted. I say an additional pleasure, since the book is above all a tale of intrigue, betrayal, courage, and social strife that is eye opening and a compulsively written tale. I knew Jess Walter from his book Beautiful Ruins which I loved, and I knew he was from Spokane, so I was excited to read his historical fiction novel set in PNW. After what I felt was a very slow start, I almost gave up. The characters and subject matter just didn't grab me despite the setting. I am SO glad I kept reading. At about the 25% mark, I was totally hooked.

With a few real-life characters the labor/socialist movement in the early 20th century, Walter creates a story that resonates with

This page turner is an historical novel set in the wild western city of Spokane Washington in the first decades of the 20th Century. The labor movement is alive and kicking in Spokane and two brothers, Gig and Rye, transients who have landed in Spokane after losing their entire family and looking for work, find themselves embroiled in a battle between the corrupt local police force and the radical unionist workers, fighting to stop corruption and for the rights of workers. They encounter brutal

I never thought I would find a book I liked more than ‚ÄúBeautiful Ruins,‚Äù but I have.

Jess Walter is quite simply a fantastic story teller. ‚ÄúThe Cold Millions‚Äù is populated by colorful characters (including some true historical figures) including bums, tramps and hobos.
Set in the Pacific Northwest (mostly Walter‚Äôs hometown of Spokane) at the start of the 20th century, this is the tale of the struggle between those who make the engine of our economy run and those who profit from it. That struggle

Well, I must say as a Spokane native -- born, raised, and still live here (with only a few short years away in Ohio for college), I certainly loved this book as Spokane itself was quite the character in this novel! Man, can Jess Walter tell a story, too. I've literally read every single thing he's put out and will continue to do so for as long as he'll keep putting things out!
Perhaps the most enjoyable part for me as the reader was that I could, quite literally, picture every part of town Jess

Fascinating story set in a rough western town, Spokane, Washington, "a boom town that just kept booming." A coming of age story of both the main character, Rye, and the town itself. The town and the river that runs through it are also "characters" in the story and conflict centers on union organizers (IWW) v. silver mine owners; police v. tramps (itinerant workers); idealism v. reality of life at that time (roughly 1909 - 1911), and other universal themes. Historic figures such as Elizabeth Gurl

I received an advance copy of this novel for review purposes. I would have finished it much sooner, but it arrived at the same time as several other ARCs.

Initially I had some difficulty getting into the book and put it aside, but the characters were haunting me so I picked it up again. I am so glad I did. Once I passed the first few chapters, Mr Walter had me hooked.

I knew a bit about the labor wars from folk music, and from tv and movies, but Mr Walter brought so much more information to me. I

Finished The Cold Millions by Jess Walter, a work of historical fiction set in Spokane in 1909. It starts a little slow but is a terrific book; it grows on you. The book captures the inequities facing working people in the early 20th century west. I have a much better understanding of the labor movement especially the IWW, The Industrial Workers of the World, members of which were commonly called ‚ÄúWobblies‚Äù. Unjust mine owners in particular used ruthless tactics to deny worker rights, like hirin

I loved Beautiful Ruins! The author has a new book? Reading it immediately!

This book is not Beautiful Ruins. It's totally different.

At first, I was disappointed. This story is bleak, sad, a little (a lot) hopeless. But you know what? It's still a beautiful story. That's what a talented writer Jess Walter is. I made myself finish it because I trusted he would take me someplace. And he did. It's an important story in a lot of ways, but you have to be willing to visit 1909 Spokane. It's not a happy

This was a good story with many well-written perspectives. Set in historical Spokane (circa 1909), it gives both history and corruption with compelling narrative.

The IWW and itinerant workers provide an excellent backdrop for this orphan story. Chapters bounced
around various characters and even a bit in time, some with cliffhangers. It refers to War and Peace in a few ways, but knowledge of that epic isn't required to enjoy this. The Cold Millions wasn't an easy book to set down, and I'm glad I

This wasnt really what I expected. Based off the union wars in the early 1900s didnt make an exciting read for me. This was more personal than anything.
What I did enjoy is there are so many novels out there about family bonds mostly involving sisters. This one was about brothers Gig and Rye. It was an interesting perspective.
I felt the story was told pretty accurate to how it was with unions and looking for work in those times. The difference between the rich and the poor showed many of the sam

Terrific book about the IWW riots and protests in Spokane 1910 partially based on the story of activist Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, a well educated, smart, petite and pregnant, great communicator Irish lass who lays the case for freedom of speech. The characters include rough cops, Pinkerton spies, and two tramps who are brothers, orphans who ride the rails in search of odd jobs to provide them food, sometimes whiskey and a rare roof over their heads. It is a compelling story from beginning to end,

The American West was hit hard this year, wild fires, drought and Pam Zhang‚Äôs How Much of These Hills Is Gold, about a silly a novel as you can imagine. Much better is Jess Walter‚Äôs The Cold Millions. The work is reminiscent of the best of E.L. Doctorow with a slight case of Larry McMurtry. If you happen to have, as I do, a predilection for labor history, so much the better. The setting is mostly 1909 Spokane and the Wobblies are on the rise.

Our protagonists are the Dolan Brothers, Rye and Gig.

This is the story of two brothers growing up during the time of the start of the Unions. Ryan and Greg are alone after the death of their parents. They are living in Spokane. The wealthy mine owners and the rich are determined to keep the poor down so they can stay wealthy. Greg gets involved in the Union. He goes to jail where the jailed go on a hunger strike. Ryan is approached by a rich man who wants information about the Unions and organizers. He doesn't understand what use the man will make

In this tale about two brothers swept up in the upheaval for workers‚Äô rights, Jess Walter turns his attention to the early stages of the labor movement in Spokane, Washington. The Cold Millions transports readers to another era (right after the turn of the 20th century) when the United States was in the midst of significant upheaval, eerily similar to what the country is experiencing in 2020. Walters vividly details life during that time period, including vaudeville stars, suffragettes, hobos, u

I've always said I don't like historical fiction, but it turns out what I meant was I don't like WWI or WWII love stories. This was about unions in the Northwest in the early 1900s, and I liked it a lot. Like I'm sure all other readers, I loved Rye, and felt a little sad for everyone. All the characters rang true for me, which is important because there were a couple of times when I thought "would that person REALLY do that?" and the answer was always yes. The epilogue was a very nice, neat endi

I‚Äôve been waiting a while for a new Jess Walter book, and now that it‚Äôs here and I‚Äôve read it I‚Äôm sad that it wasn‚Äôt quite worth the wait. The book isn‚Äôt bad, and Walter‚Äôs prose is still just as sharp and impressive as it‚Äôs always been, but something about the story just never clicked for me. This is another novel that bogs itself down by trying to tell a lot of stories in one succinct package, and it doesn‚Äôt always work for me. While the scope is grand, I never got that intimate introspection t

Those stars are an average - five for concept, three for execution. The story is rushed, the tone is inconsistent, the exposition is clunky, and there are a couple of silly jokes - the 30-something burlesque performer has a "cougar" act, and a union turncoat buys gloves made of weasel fur. The Cold Millions is a well researched historical fiction, that mixes in some truth, set in Spokane during the union breaking activity of 1909.
I think this story further radicalized me toward a pro-union stance - and even though the issues were different than today (I rarely arrive to a new town hiding on a train looking for work) the class strutures and strictures are still in place.
We have several POV characters (arguably too many, but they are all fleshed out and with clear different charact

I was surprised by how much I enjoyed this book. Normally historical fiction that centers on two men in the early 1900s isn't something I would normally go for but the beautiful writing and well-rounded characters completely transported me into another universe that I was deeply invested in. I'm not too familiar with this time period so I definitely learned a lot but I appreciated all the classical literary elements the author incorporated into the novel which made it seem like a quintessential

Set in Spokane, WA in the early 1900s, I wasn't completely sure at the outset of this book that I was going to enjoy it. Well, I was wrong! Actually, after what I thought was a bit of a slow start in this piece of historical fiction, I fell in love with the characters, their various situations/plights and even the setting! It's a fun book full of characters that come to life through Walter's meticulous writing. The descriptions, word choice and conversations are pitch perfect really making the t

Jess Walter seems to pick a new genre with each new novel. This time he's written a historical fiction involving Spokane, Washington and the early days of the rise of labor unions. While using the beginning as his premise, he more than makes clear that workers still need and deserve protection from those who would take advantage of us. This isn't a topic that generally interests me, but this is a page-turner and a great read. His characters are always human, surprising and compelling. I really c

To me, not only was this a book about the free speech riots involving the Wobblies (International Workers of the World), it also is a parallel to events today. Combining fictional characters with read characters. Although I was a big confused in the beginning chapters with introduction to the fictional characters, the storyline soon fell into place as Rye and Gig Dolan, orphans forced into the lives of tramps and their involvement in the IWW movement. It‚Äôs a novel filled with empathy for men who

This is the kind of rollicking historical fiction that reminds me mostly of the work of E. L. Doctorow, with its huge cast consisting of both fictional and real characters, and its opening up of a segment of American history that seldom gets a close look in history classes. Set in Washington State in 1909, Spokane but also Seattle, we learn of the union movement, stumping for free speech, the manipulators, the anarchists, the crooks, the rascals and the saints, mostly told through the eyes of tw

I devoured this gripping book. I love Walter's versatility: here's again a new setting for him, timewise. It's Spokane, as in much of his work, but (mainly) 1909, and the context is labor and politics. I suppose the nature of work, justice, crime, and politics keep cropping up in most of his stuff, but always in a refreshing and new way, with fantastic characters, awesome prose, and a peculiar hopefulness even when things are grim.

what a fantastic book. i have loved everything walter has written and this book is no exception.

part ragtime, part red dead redemption II, part horatio alger, set in (mostly) spokane in the early 1900s: well-crafted characters, socialism, capitalism, labor rights, land development, people just trying to make their way. loved every page, loved the way that there are pages set aside to give character exposition every few chapters.

well written, sharp and relatable characters (drawn from history bu

Author Jess Walter takes readers to a time even more tumultuous than the present in THE COLD MILLIONS a sweeping tale of murder, lust, greed and hardship in early 1900s America. His unique ability to create characters that enter the story, even briefly, yet make indelible marks on the plot and readers‚Äô imaginations, is truly remarkable. Orphans, all Ryan wanted was to establish a home with his adored older brother Gig, but the times in Spokane were too hard and unfair to play it straight.

Thank you HarperCollins for the free arc via Edelweiss. I cannot believe it has been 7 yrs since Beautiful Ruins was written which I loved. My enjoyment of that book made me want to read this historical fiction and I was not disappointed. The author does a great job of weaving historical facts into the storyline and creating interesting characters. I read the book in two sittings I was so involved with the story. Full disclosure, I grew up in the town the book is set in and know many locations but only just tiny bits of the history around the story, so I was easily taken in...but my goodness this is a splendid book. To say it is political betrays the humanity and passion of the story.

A deeply satisfying tale of brotherhood, adventure, politics, organizing and manhood. This was outstanding. Set against the background of wealth disparity, oppression of racial and ethnic minorities, and labor unrest, in an era in which free speech was suppressed with the help of brutal police tactics. Kind of like today, only with Model T's and a lot more trains.

This just wasn't for me; I tried. It's not that well written for one thing, but the most compelling reason for me not to read more than 56 pages was the rough language and scenarios--which seemed to get worse as the story progressed. This is a perfect historical fiction recommendation. The accurate portrayal of the labor strife in Spokane Washington in 1909 is fascinating. Cher Ami and Major Whittlesey, Devil in the White City (I know its not fiction, but it feels like it), are two that come to mind. The fictional characters are lovable and tragic. Not the best but just makes five star. Entertaining and actually quite educational. Didn‚Äôt realize how factual it was till I Wikipediaed it. A very realistic portrait of labor wars in the early 1900‚Äôs. Makes you realize how much we take for granted. Maybe it isn‚Äôt fair, but I can‚Äôt help comparing this to The Zero and Citizen Vince which are very different books. The book was good and I learned a lot but not my favorite Walter book.
