Thanks for the ARC @harpercollins

Another great read by Jess Walter. A bit slow at the very start, but that changed quickly.

Historical fiction populated with interesting non-fiction events and figures such as the Free Speech Law fight in 1909 Spokane, Washington and Elizabeth Gurley Flynn.

Also, 104 years ago today on November 5, 1916, The Bloody Sunday Everett Massacre played out at the dock in Everett, Washington.

Much like many Timothy Egan's books, Walter enriches the knowledge of his grateful readers.

If you told me to read a fictionalized version of labor strikes and riots in 1900s Spokane Washington, I would say no thank you, but somehow Jess Walter manages to make this interesting to me. I have loved every book this man has ever written, as it turns out. I'm only not giving this a 5 because it wasn't very propulsive, every time I set it aside I wasn't rushing to get back to it, but once I did, I became engrossed again. The man can write anything, is what I'm saying.

An incredible story told superbly, it alternates between first person-- allowing the reader to dive deep into various characters -- and third person-- allowing the reader to see the story unfold as a whole-- without a hick-up. The era was a fascinating slice of the battle for workers' rights centering around the 1910 free speech protests in Spokane, WA. Corruption, lies, double-cross, victims, villains, heroes, love, faith, sacrifice, and survival, this story swept me up and brought me home.

After loving Beautiful Ruins, was really looking forward to Walter's newest book. The Cold Millions is a tale built amongst the struggle in the early twentieth century for free speech, unionism, and ending the stranglehold that the wealthy had over the workers. Much like Steinbech's East of Eden and Tolstoy's War and Peace (which figures into the novel), the characters are part of the story of the changing times. A talented writer.

Wow! What a book. I suspect it will be in line for awards.
Walter is using local history as a foundation for his poignant and fascinating story. It is well written, has an interesting format, and many twists. Walter knows local history but the story could be about many other areas during the early years of the 20th century. He writes about class struggles, power-grabbing officials, greedy businessmen, labor leaders, women's rights/roles, and the struggles of laborers.

I loved We Live in Water but disliked Beautiful Ruins, and this was somewhere in between. I liked it well enough to finish reading it, but wasn't rushing back to it when I had to put it down. It should do well this fall because it's extremely topical, though, and has some great things to say about the right to protest.

Historical fiction novel centered on Spokane, WA in the early 1900's. The Wobblies (members of the Industrial Workers of the World) are trying to organize and real life activist Elizabeth Gurley Flynn really gets things stirred up. This novel reminded me a lot of Steinbeck--both in the subject matter and the misfit main characters that give this story so much heart. Very good read!

The novel is set in Spokane, Washington in the early 1900s. We meet the Dolan brothers, dirt poor and trying to get by as best they can. Gig becomes involved with a labor union, the IWW. Rye lucks into a low paying but steady job. The book is their story, but with lots of historical background and a cast of fascinating characters. Great read!

As a listener on an Audible Edition of the book, l was taken back to a more rough and tumble time (mostly 1909) to visit most often in the area of where seven railroads converged to make it the ‚Äúhappening place‚Äù of the moment and the author‚Äôs hometown: the city of Spokane! Spokane was less wild than it had been but still had a ways to go for safety and coming of age. We
find ourselves here, in an isolated, booming and breathtakingly beautiful place at a momentous historical time. We are glad to

Historical fiction at its best! Two orphaned brothers set out to make a good life for themselves. Along the way they learn about women, the rights of women, the good cops, the bad cops, and what it takes to survive in a world of good and evil. The characters in this book take us on a journey through early America-not always an easy place to navigate.

Of particular interest to people from the Spokane area who will recognize all the streets, buildings and historical names, I think this book should be classified as historical fiction instead of fiction. I felt like I was living in 1909 in Spokane and traveling to places like Lind, WA. and Taft, Montana. Jess Walters delivers another highly readable novel.

I had heard of the Wobblies in school but this book paints a wonderful picture of the labor unions and the class stuggle came to Spokane. This book is timely at any time, because although some of the injustices the characters experienced are history some are very much contemporary. The characters are warmly portrayed, even the antagonists.

Powerful, painful, but soo well done. The power of fiction to bring to life a small incident in the history of labor relations and make it universal. Walter brings the history of his hometown to life with this gritty, emotional story. I highly recommend the auditory version; it really brings the personalities forward.

The epilogue ties the book together. Felt disjointed at times but glad I finished. Two brothers trying to make their way with a world of obstacles in front of them. The division in the country between people believing they were right seems familiar today as in the 60s and at other times.

Time and patience....true for Tolstoy, true for Rye and true for most of us.

Just never got into the story, too many characters too much skimming over their motives and personal stories.. Plus I'm way too biased again all the left.. We all know all of this ends, some countries still reeling from the effect of the communists in power. I didn't like any of the characters here, never cared for any kf them. Too much casual violence and too many weird people.

This is a phenomenal story. I listened to it on audible and the performances were great, but the writing is so good I wished I'd read it. I might still. This goes into my favorite Pacific Northwest fiction shelf, there with Kesey's Sometimes a Great Notion and Duncan's Brothers K. Walters has the same gift for characters-both people & places.

Praise for the working man

Great story and characters about the free speech movement and riots in Spokane in 1909 . Fictional characters are mixed with real actors in the events such as Elizabeth Flynn a labor organizer who went on to head the American Communist party. Also a vivid picture of what the West was like in the early 20th century.

Was just an alright read for me. I got more into the characters and time period as I went, but characters felt a bit distant or detached.

This is the second novel I've read by Jess Walter and both have been just okay, whereas others love them. Can't quite put my finger on why they don't click for me...

Audiobook

If I could give this book 10 stars, I would. Although it took a little while to get acclimated to the topic, I became enraptured with the pacing of this novel, the use of multiple voices and the coverage of events in the late 1800s. Well researched, although still a work of fiction, the author made the characters come alive. Highly recommended.

Such great characters!!! I would never guess that a book written about workers in the early 1900s would be interesting, but here we are. Rye is young and impressionable, and he's smart and thoughtful. I cheered for him from start to finish along with the other cast of characters. The women are fierce and independent. What a gem!

I was hesitant after reading the description of this book because it didn‚Äôt seem like my typical interest. Boy am I glad I didn‚Äôt listen. The writing is beautiful. I could not put this book down and finished it in one day.

Nothing can touch my love for and enchantment by #beautifulruins but #thecoldmillions charmed me right out of the blue with all the quirky side characters and subplots. I had no idea I was interested in this history and way of life, but I was. Couldn‚Äôt put it down. #netgalley

May be my favorite read of the year so far. A beautiful fictionalization of history. Really brings the plight and characters to life. The reader is transported into the life of these characters with ease, almost unsettlingly so.

Made me bust out some old Pete Seeger and Utah Phillips records.

I was starting to think I'd found all the books set in Seattle/Washington state, but boom! Here's a whole new author to explore. Good book, too. In depth, historical, and epic without resorting to doorstop size.

Walter‚Äôs most impressive achievement to date. It succeeds in every ambition to which it aspires. It‚Äôs a thrilling and engrossing historical novel, as well as a searing condemnation of inequality that persists in the modern era.

A great yarn! Walter is such an accomplished novelist. He manages multiple characters voices and plot lines - all feel real and hold the reader's attention. Bonus: I knew very little about the history Walter covers in this novel and many characters are based in real life!

3.5 rounded up.

I like historical fiction.
I was amused by how often the train station and the courthouse were mentioned so I had to see a picture of them from the early 1900s.

This book will make for a good bookclub discussion.

Excellent storytelling with profound ideas

A quasi-historical account of significant times which echo the culture wars of today. The story weaves together multiple themes with engaging characters and compelling action.

Loved the multicast narration. Ry Dolan definitely had a delightful Ponyboy feel to him. Grittier and a whole lot sadder than Beautiful Ruins but I think readers will enjoy it. This will be on my best of 2020 list.

Unbelievably well done. If there were an oscars for book, this one would win the book of the year. Author did his research and out heart and soul into the characters and story. 10 stars if I could. One of my favorites.

I tried hard to get into this book, but it was just boring. I was charmed by the stories of Spokane, which will always hold a special place in my heart, but this will end up on my DNF list because 50 pages in, I just felt like I was wasting my time.
I haven't read this yet...waiting for it to be released!
Early 20th Century. A gripping novel of the Dolan brothers dream of a better world. Thankyou Goodreads for this free book.
library hold 10-29-2020
Awesome
4.5 I loved the writing, the characters, all of it.
Loved parts of it; other parts dragged. Still would recommend this to those who like historical fiction.
A fast paced novel
this was an okay book, I found it hard to follow, too many characters, too much jumping around, and I really did not like the main characters at all.
Two brothers, Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, and miners turmoil in Spokane WA. Satisfying read.

Yes! I'm so excited to have received this review copy!

Many thanks to the publisher Penguin General UK and Netgalley for providing me with it!

Cool, confident, planning everything down to the letter, rarely a misstep, there is nothing that she can't do, when she puts her mind to it. That includes murdering men who she deems deserving of a well planned and fitting death. They Never Learn is a dark and devious psychological thriller about a female professor who murders men who have committed unspeakable acts of abuse against women.

Two women at Gorman University, one a student, the other a professor, are united in bringing down the perpetrators of sexual assault.

Carly is a shy and awkward, college freshman. She is scared to open up and let people know the real her. Struggling to fit in, while at the same time t

It's so refreshing to find an author who isn't afraid to "go there", if you know what I mean. The premise behind They Never Learn is a modern classic; feminist serial killing told in a thrilling manner. The beauty of this story is that we know who is doing the killing at the beginning of the book, but we don't truly know what led her to it until the plot unravels in the second half. I thi

A dark and twisted psychological thriller, about two women who enjoy giving bad men what they deserve...


Scarlett is an English professor at Gormon University. She is also a serial killer, a vigilante doling out punishment to the rapists and the abusers of the world. Her life is fine, until the university starts looking into the er..large body count on campus! Anxious and enraged, she loses control with her latest victim and puts everything at risk.

Scarlett is a serial killer. She has been killing for 16 years. She has some very good reasons. She is a professor at Gorman University and is very smart and well-respected. She is driven to kill by a desire to seek revenge on men who take advantage of their power over women sexually.

Carly is a shy girl starting her freshman year at Gorman. She has a difficult family situation and doesn't have any friends at first. Once she foun

Easily one of the most binge worthy books of 2020.

I was hesitant to pick up Layne Fargo's They Never Learn because her debut and I didn't end on a good note, but this is literally proof that you should always read a book that catches your eye, regardless of prior experience with the author. I could not put this book down at all and read it in two sittings. The story is everything that I would want in a female Dexter spin off‚Äîa feminist, queer, protagonist; coming for the throats of terrible

They Never Learn was the most fun I've had with a book in ages.  It's far from perfect (it notably leans into an obsession with the glam femme fatale in a way that wouldn't have been out of place with mid-2000s feminist media), but I'm just going to leave that criticism at the door because I had such a damn good time reading this.

It follows Scarlett, a professor-turned-vigilante serial killer who spends her evenings tracking down and murdering men who have abused women.  We also follow a student

They Never Learn is Layne Fargo's sophomore novel. I really liked it, although I found the ending to be too neat for my tastes, I suspect it will please readers more than her first novel, Temper, which had a much more nebulous ending.

They Never Learn has two storylines, the first being about a murderous professor named Scarlett, who as the novel opens is revealed to be a serial killer who kills men who she feels deserve to die. The second strand is about a freshman at the same college named Carl

Wow, I really enjoyed this one!!

Reminded me of Dexter - in this case it's about a female serial killer, calculating and fascinating. Both, Scarlett and Carla had interesting storylines and I had a great time with this fresh and compelling read. Wouldn't say no to a sequel.

*This is an almost spoiler-free review. It is all safe apart from my second complaint which has been hidden for those who haven't yet read the book.*

This novella is not only chock full of interesting plotlines and great character work, but it also contains within it so much more than I was expecting in terms of both lore, world building and references to (and straight up knowledge of) the wider Cosmere.
I was captivated enough to read Dawnshard in a single day and it was generous with it's length

Dawnshard is another illuminating and beautifully crafted piece in the Cosmere puzzle.

Every time a new Stormlight Archive story gets released my excitement goes through the roof. There is no reading I enjoy more, and I am so thankful that I am lucky enough to be getting not only one, but two new Cosmere stories this year!

Dawnshard is a novella, and as such shorter than your average SA book, but it‚Äôs still longer than Brandon planned and comes in at about 200 pages. Let me tell you though, I

As soon as I got access to Dawnshard through the Kickstarter, I immediately started reading. Dawnshard is an incredible and intricately woven story that stands alone while also expanding the Cosmere in significant ways.

Dawnshard mostly follow Rysn with The Lopen sprinkled throughout. When the perspectives for the novella were first announced, I was slightly disappointed since The Lopen isn‚Äôt my favourite character. I find him to be slightly annoying at times. The amount I see him in the main se

Cosmere fans, you're in for such a treat because I was not expecting such a stunning revelation. But not only do we get loads of lore and Cosmere connections in this, the character development of these two side characters from the main series was fantastic! And there's excellent representation of those who are disabled or people who are 'different'. Brilliant empathetic writing all round without sacrificing plot, pace and worldbuilding.

Full RTC.

Post-release review: this was such an amazing entry not only to the Stormlight Archive but also to the Cosmere as a whole. Things from across the Cosmere are finally starting to come together, and more inner-workings are being made clear. Or maybe not clear lol, but not quite as obfuscated.

Between Mistborn: Secret History, Edgedancer, and now Dawnshard, these shorter novellas really allow Sanderson to flex the (constantly twitching) "side-story muscle" that is so clearly difficult for him to manage in the main series. I admit that the interludes in The Stormlight Archive are my weakest knowledge points in the entire series. I will also admit that shorter fiction has never been something I'm particularly drawn to.

Because writing 1200+ page books every three years alongside smaller YA books isn‚Äôt enough, Brandon Sanderson has also decided to write novellas for the Stormlight Archives. This most recent novella, Dawnshard, (which is really a short novel, but who‚Äôs counting) was included as part of the kickstarter of The Way of Kings leatherbounds and I was able to get my ebook copy just a couple days ago.

Something that makes you curious about what's going on in the wider world while still being contained enough to be a solitary story.

Rsyn, The Lopen, Chiri-chiri, Cord, and others take a pirate-like boat trip to a mysterious island (view spoiler)

I have a lot of thoughts on this book, I'll try to summarize them.

This is an adventure book, but not in the grander traditions folks are used to from the Stormlight Archives. This is a slower paced novella with less of a sense of impending doom. This, the latest instalment in the stormlight archive does not disappoint. Dawnshard is a thoroughly enjoyable, humorous and also touching story from the viewpoint of Rysn and The Lopen.

One complaint - this kindle edition was seriously overpriced, and for the money, it was really short.

Dawnshard was great after having read basically the entire Cosmere within the past year. There are so many new tidbits of Cosmere lore added. Wonderful and meaningful and just really fun to read. 5 stars plus. This book, the timing of release, and the content, altogether feels like a love letter from Brandon Sanderson's to his committed Cosmere fans. The second Stormlight novella does not disappoint.

Sanderson does great by Rysn, the handicapped protagonist. Her struggles keep the book grounded and make her ascendance even more gratifying. Plus she is definitely going to end up with a flying wheelchair and I am here for it.

Brandon Sanderson, you beautiful son of a bitch!

It's been a while since I last read a cosmere novel. Almost long enough for me to start to question my belief in Brandons superiority. There are a lot of good books out there, after all. Now, after blowing through Dawnshard, I feel silly. The Brandon pedistal ain't high enough. All hail the king.

Top marks from me. This exceeded expectations (though by now I ought to know Sanderson usually will...) and I would strongly advise anyone reading the Stormlight Archive to NOT skip this!!!

Enjoyed this significantly more than Edgedancer, the previous Stormlight novella. In fact, I think this is probably my favorite of all the various novellas and short stories Sanderson has written. It has everything!

Dawnshard is better than Edgedancer, being a fast, fun and important novella to the Stormlight Archive and probably the whole cosmere.

There's not too much to say, because this is really short, but although it's longer than all the other cosmere novellas (this actually isn't a novella, but that's not really important), Dawnshard is faster and better than most of them. This book was a pleasant surprise before Rhythm of War comes out two weeks from now (as of Nov 6).

This is a novella with a singular focus of a trip undertaken by the main characters to a mystical island. The characters are also a pleasant surprise - the Lopen and Huio especially are fleshed out more from their appearances on the main Stormlight novels. We now understand them so much better. Rysn is well written too, but Cord was just fine. But it feels like they're all being set up for later.

4 stars, only because the standards set by Sanderson are in the fucking stratosphere.

Great short story that fits perfectly inbetween Oathbringer and Rhythm of War (and really helps with the wait for the latter). As always with a Sanderson novel there are some really intriguing ideas and some really spicy implications for the cosmere (can't wait to read some theories).

It's been fun to have an appetizer for rhythm of War and the book did exactly what I wanted it to - distract me from the long wait that now begins again.

*small spoile

I read this novella right after finishing Oathbringer and am in eager anticipation of starting to read Rhythm of War when it is released in a few days. Overall it was very satisfying. One thing I always enjoy about reading Sanderson books is way he can illustrate in very relatable ways important aspects of the human condition, even though his stories are extremely fantastical. Wow. For what is essentially a side piece to the main Stormlight series, I was shocked at how pertinent this story was. Not just to the Stormlight Archive, but the Cosmere and its fate as a whole.

Novellas like these just show that one should pay very close attention to the Interludes in the main books, as they are littered with Easter eggs and clues for future projects. It's made we want to go back and read Edgedancer, as I don't think I appreciated the gravity of that at the time.

4.5 stars. It's a little slow in the first half, and I'm not sure that the second half would make up for it on its own. However, for the Cosmere aware reader, the secrets revealed are amazing and astounding. No spoilers, but let's just say that the dawnshards are not what I thought they were.

I loved Rysn's heroics at the climax, and we see more depth and growth of character from the Lopen than anything we've seen from the other Stormlight books. This is a solid and important addition the Stormli

Absolutely amazing. Much like Edgedancer, it was great to see some of the stranger parts of Roshar get fleshed out, and Rysn has grown so much as a character. Giving her her own novella was a perfect capstone to her arc and I can't wait to see what comes next.

High seas and exploration books are always fun in general and this one really knocks it out of the park. Strong Voyage of the Dawn Treader vibes going on, in the best way.

A fun read that focuses on the interesting side characters of Rysn and The Lopen. I appreciate Brandon's diligence to get the details of Rysn's handicap accurate. This is a Stormlight novella (a long novella) that was made available last week as part of the recent Kickstarter that Brandon did for the leather bound edition of The Way of Kings. It's self-contained, but you really benefit from knowing the backstory of several of the characters. It was also a very enjoyable way of bringing the whole Stormlight universe back into my fore-brain after three years, ready for Rhythm of War which is coming out in about ten days time.

Besides being one of the shortest books ever (thanks, Brandon Sanderson, for thinking a novel-length book is ‚Äúshort‚Äù), Dawnshard was a lot of fun.

Getting the perspectives of The Lopen and Rysn was entertaining to say the least, and there were some powerful messages in the story as well. Exciting action and some juicy cosmere tidbits to boot. Let‚Äôs just say that, as I anticipate the release of Rhythm of War, Dawnshard was far too short.

This is certainly a far shorter novel (technically a novella) than Brandon's normal fare and it certainly was a much smaller affair though still packed with a lot of juicy details. Frankly, I'm surprised there was as much relevant information for the Cosmere here. I loved reading Rysh, Lopen and Cord. I wish there was an infinite pages to follow side chracters go on their own journey and path. Now I can't wait for the 4th stormlight book. Here we go!

4.5 / 5

Well that certainly was A LOT of informations.

This is probably my new favourite of Sanderson's companion short stories - probably because it didn't feel so much like a random "side quest", but far more integral to the overall story. Several characters we have met before, and it was nice to get to know them better. The pacing was good (which is often a problem I have with his work), and the plot was good. Not a super exciting installment, but I did enjoy it.

Okay, so, *that* happened.

Wow.

I was expecting a fill-in-the-gaps-btween-novels piece, similar to Edgedancer.

I was not expecting....well....that.

Which is to say, Dawnshard is one of the most important installments in the Cosmere.

And I am very excited to see that one of my favorite characters, who thusfar has had a very minor role in the Stormlight series, may soon become one of the most important figures in Sanderson's mythos.

Rysn is one of my favorite side characters and I was so unbelievably happy to read her novella!! She's so great. I enjoyed the story as well and as per usual Brandon Sanderson fashion, I have a ton more questions!!!

My only complaint is Lopen. I really can't stand his character mostly. I don't understand why anyone thinks he's funny or a fun character, he's just so annoying. However, it seems at the end there may be some changes in his character so we'll hopefully see if he gets tolerable.

Truth be told, I don't expect to like Rhythm of War as much as I liked this tightly written, just plain fun, novella. Turns out when restricted to a shorter format and to exploring the corners, edges and side-characters of Roshar, I find myself entertained and compelled just as much, if not more than in the (much, much) longer novels. It helps that Rysn has always been a highlight of the main novels' interludes, and now finds herself undeniably among the best characters of the series.

Overall, I loved this book. Mostly on the lighter side, which is what I'm looking for these days. Lopen and Rysn were great as main POV characters, as were some of the side characters. The tidbits for overall Cosmere was unexpected.

If I had to nitpick, there were plenty of things happening that it would've needed a much longer book to give them justice, especially the decisions made in the climax.

It is a novella. Never expect too much from a Novella, but it was still a good one.

I really missed this world, and even if The Lopen was the only character that featured in the main parts of the previous books, he was still awesome as always.

And Sanderson putting so much character development into Rysn in some 100 pages shows how great of a storyteller he is.

Also the ending leaves us with more questions than answers as always. Can‚Äôt wait for RoW release next week. HYPE!

I loved this book. Heartfelt, positive story. I‚Äôm a sucker for stories that explore new places, creating something new, and making even small, side characters awesome. Rysn shines all over in the book. The amount of work Brandon has done for Rhysn is to be appreciated.

This book has significant Cosmere mysteries. I really liked how he gives just enough information to make fans hungry for more.

I have already finished part 1 of ROW. Need to wait only 2 more days. Yippee.

Definitely enjoyed this addition! I was so glad to see some characters appear and glad to delve into a side character more. I love the perspective of the main character, a unique one you don't see often in literature. This novella also makes the mysteries of Roshar and the Cosmere all the more intriguing.

I did feel that some of the plot was too convenient and a solution to a previous problem too easily solved, pushing believability, thus the four stars.

Fantastic, an easy 5! Some of my favorite side-characters teaming up to go to my favorite side-location to reveal some majorly central new lore. This is basically the perfect book for me. Hard to explain exactly what I mean without going into specifics but this short novel not only majorly advances characters I DO like, it was a huge step forward for one character I have so far really been disliking.

Without spoiling anything this is absolutely required reading for Stormlight and Cosmere fans.

I LOVED THIS SO FREAKING MUCH!!!!

This was seriously SO much better than I was expecting???? I mean, I shouldn‚Äôt doubt a Sanderson book... but novellas are normally boring guys- filler books. THIS THOUGH!? That was the most fun and depressingly gross book I‚Äôve read in Fantasy!!

(I think I need more books written on ships)

I‚Äôm gonna read Edgedancer next (I skipped it cause I don‚Äôt like novellas- don‚Äôt come at me) because I loved this so much, I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôll love it too!!

Truly, truly exception. Every sentence is filled with purpose, and every event is rich with lore. I would say this novella requires not just knowledge of the previous Stormlight books, but as many others as you can get read.

I read this book in two sittings and the only reason it took two is that I started reading it too late in the evening and literally could not stay awake long enough to finish it.

It's a lovely novella that adds interesting pieces to the Cosmere-puzzle (at least for me who haven't read so many Cosmere books yet), and lets you get closer to characters you haven't gotten the chance to spend so much time with.

This Novella features some of the minor characters from the Stormlight Archive. The characters we see in the interludes. Great little bonus story in the stormlight universe.

Like many Reacher fans, I was alarmed to read that author Lee Child (pseudonym of James Grant) (1954-) was retiring and passing his franchise over to his younger brother Andrew Grant (1968-).

I forgot this was coming, so it was a pleasant surprise-- and completely destroyed all the plans I had for today.

The Sentinel is the 25th novel featuring Jack Reacher and cowritten by Lee Child and his younger brother, Andrew, who according to reports is assuming authorship of the series going forward. After leaving the US Army as a major in its military police unit at age 36, Reacher roams the United States taking odd jobs and investigating suspicious and frequently dangerous situations.

Barkley Cove, North Carolina- 1969

This one is a treasure - a book to be read slowly and every word savoured. An absolute delight. And keep the tissues handy, you will need them.

I didn't exactly finish this book. I lacked the steam to do it. I didn't have the stamina. This book has no real story worth remembering.

Where the Crawdads Sing is a book that‚Äôs massively praised worldwide, and it lives up to all the hype.

It doesn‚Äôt matter whether you read literary fiction or not, if you‚Äôve visited Amazon or a bookstore in 2019, it‚Äôs quite likely that you‚Äôve heard about Where the Crawdads Sing, Delia Owens‚Äôs FIRST novel that‚Äôs praised and hit bestseller everywhere. This book destroyed me! I wish I could give it 10 stars. It‚Äôs a deeply emotional, bittersweet, and heart breaking coming-of-age story that centers around a young girl, Kya, growing up in a remote shack in the marshes of North Carolina. She‚Äôs dismissed as white trash by the inhabitants of the local town, and abandoned by her family and everyone she‚Äôs ever cared about. Where the Crawdads Sing was beautiful, sad and somewhat joyful. Set in the 1950s and 1960s in the marshlands of North Carolina, the story focuses on Kya, who at age 6 is essentially abandoned in a shack by her whole family. Somehow, with very little help, she manages to raise herself, surviving on her love for and deep understanding of the natural world. In parallel, the story focuses on a murder that takes place in 1969. Slowly, Kya‚Äôs life and the unsolved murder come together. Th

Kya Clark has never known anyplace other than the marshes around Barclay Cove, North Carolina. Her impoverished family splintered because of her abusive alcoholic father and eventually she was left alone at the tender age of eleven when he walked away and never returned. Kya managed to support herself by selling mussels to a kind owner of a marina and learned to read with the help of a friend. But more importantly, she learned about life through the ecology and wildlife in the marshes.

The image of her mother walking away is something that will stay with Kya, the Marsh girl, for a lifetime.  Only six years old, barefoot, bedraggled, and now abandoned.  Kya is left to fend for herself in the marsh. She identifies with the insects and the birds, learning the behaviors that run parallel to those of humans.  What she knows best is how to be alone.  The 'soggy quiet' of the swamp is palpable, the cacophony of cawing crows as thrilling as it is earsplitting.

How do you trust when you've been abandoned over and over again? Kya's mother left her abusive husband when Kya was only six. Then, one by one, her siblings left. When Kya was ten, her father had turned to the bottle again and walked out the door of their shack. She learned to survive by living off the land in a coastal marsh in North Carolina. Where do the crawdads sing?

Way out yonder, "in the dark reaches of the marsh."

Really lovely writing! This debut novel does a nice job of combining the heartbreaking story of an abandoned (at age 7!) young girl growing up in the marsh area off the coast of North Carolina in the 50's and 60's, a whodunnit murder mystery and a little bit of romance. I felt like I really was there in the marshes with Kya Clark, feeling a part of nature but wanting human connections as well.

Author Delia Owens is a wildlife scientist and an award-winning nature writer. Although Where the Crawdads Sing is her debut novel in fiction, the world of writing is not foreign to her and it shows. Her experience in both nature and the written word swims through the pages of this novel and pulls the reader into a wild North Carolina marshland where isolation makes way for an entire new world. Kya Clark (aka The Marsh Girl) was left to fend for herself at a young age. She survived but not witho

A lyrical, beautiful story of a young girl's coming of age under difficult and unusual circumstances.
Kya is 6 yrs old when her mother left their family. She is eventually deserted by all her family. So by the age of 10, she is all alone in the swamps of North Carolina. She manages to survive and thrive and learn about her surrounding world. Two different boys/men come into her life- Tate and Chase and through both of them, her life changes.

All the stars! This is sure to be one of my top reads of 2018! An achingly beautiful and tender story, where the nature-filled coastal marshes of N. Carolina are fully alive and integral to the story. It's a story of small coastal town life and an abandoned child who becomes one with the wilderness she lives in. It's a story of her struggle for acceptance from a town that doesn't understand her, and the complexities of love with the one who knows her the deepest. It's a story that blends coming

Extremely quick read for this wonderful book! I never considered the marshland to be beautiful before.

The story and mystery is centered around the simple wholesomeness of Kya and her love of the marsh and all its creatures. Although the beginning was a bit slow, I was drawn in by the vivid characters. This is a story that invokes so many emotions: joy, pain, disappointment, and betrayal. It will linger with me for many days to come... I highly recommend!

This is the 27th Stephanie Plum book and pretty much follows the formula of her previous capers. This spectacularly inept bounty hunter with a conflicted love life, shares her adventures with her friend, an oversized, confident former ‚Äúsatisfaction‚Äù worker and her recently widowed grandmother. This is a Humor Cozy Mystery, and this is the 27th book in the Stephanie Plum series. I love the Plum series. I have misses Ranger in the last a couple of books before this one, and I am so happy Ranger is back in this book. I love the Grandma Mazur character. I found this book so funny and great. It was a Stephanie Plum novel...she goes to get food with Lula (donuts or cluck in a bucket), they get shot at, asks Ranger for some help, blows up a car or two, waffles between her relationships with Morelli and Ranger, and ultimately gets the bad guy.

Not worth the wait!

When I read number 27 was going to be the last in the series I couldn't wait. Finally we'd get to know who she picked Joe or Ranger. As it was the final book I expected more then we got. We got more cars crashed. Lula same as always and Rex still living in a soup can.

Another fun novel that made me laugh out loud many times. Stephanie is finally finding her true path while searching for Grandma's dead husband's treasure, blowing up cars, and having both Ranger and Morelli protect her while vying for her attention. I LOVED this one! So full of classic Stephanie Plum moments that make me stay up way too late at night wanting to read more. Many laugh out loud moments, cars blowing up, Grandma Mazur craziness, and of course Lula, Ranger, and Morelli. The only thing really "missing" was more of Morelli and Bob. I never get tired of these characters and their shenanigans. Anytime I'm having a rough day I can pull out one of these books (I have them all in hardback) and know I'm going to laugh and relax.

Another cute and quirky book in the series with the usual laugh out loud moments! Really enjoyed Ranger having a bigger part in the love triangle again. Glad to to see Stephanie actually get a few good hits onto the bad guys and that Ranger and Morelli didn't have to completely rescue her, but at the same I was disappointed, because I'm a sucker for the whole damsel in distress situation. I love when a character evolves! I loved meeting Gabriela, too and can‚Äôt wait for that story! I also think she will figure out what she wants. Go Stephanie!

This is book 27 in the Stephanie Plum series and I just love this series. It was a fun mystery with excellent characters. Stephanie the bounty hunter and Lulu her co-worker are hilarious together. I would like to see Stephanie grow, pick one of the guys, still be a bounty hunter, but upgrade poor Stephanie. She's been so miserable for the last few books.

I was wondering if the change in title style would mean that this was the end of Stephanie Plum as we know it. I had really been struggling with this series, but liked this book much better than the last couple. It was more about the mystery and slightly less about the love triangle.

Very disappointed. Each book gets worse and worse. I understand the writers use ghostwriters, however this novel comes off more as fan fiction. Fortune and Glory (Stephanie Plum #27) was a fun read and an excellent election distraction. Stephanie goes on another adventure with Morelli and Ranger in the wings. Stephanie Plum

Another HIT!!!!

I absolutely LOVE Stephanie Plum as a character. She never fails to amuse me. I love that she has these two great men that I hope she never chooses between. I would be heartbroken if she ever does. Janet Evanovich has done it again. I always look forward to the antics Stephanie Plum will be getting into in each of the books, and this one does not disappoint. This was great

I love the characters in this series. There is always at least one part that makes me laugh out loud. The story seems outrageous but exactly what is expected from the group. I look forward to reading the next in the series,well written and very entertaining

I liked it but didn't love it and at points skimmed to just move it along. I liked 26 and had hopes for this one but it's still the same old stuff mostly. Every time I read a new Stephanie Plum book, I think "this is the best one yet!"

I've been #TeamRanger from the start but lately I've been leaning towards #TeamMorelli. Am I maturing or have I finally gotten over Joe's wild youth? Or is it Bob? It might be Bob. Gotta love a guy with a dog!

I've read or listened to every book in the series. I have always loved these characters, but it's just getting tired. There was real potential with the treasure-hunting story line, but it fell flat. I was so looking forward to Fortune and Glory by Janet Evanovich, but this one was pretty much a dud for me.

3 Stars

Best Yet!

Janet Evanovich never ceases to amaze. She is so talented, and just when you think her stories have hit their apex for entertainment, Evanovich comes up with one even better. These books are always funny and intriguing, but #27 is the best yet. It's a mile a minute romp through a mystery with slapstick action and incredibly clever dialogue. Don't miss this one!

Stephanie is at it again!

Once again I had the best time reading a Stephanie Plum book by Janet Evanovich. I enjoyed all the usual players, but was really happy that Ranger played a bigger role. I also enjoyed meeting a new character, Potts. Hope we see him again. In this crazy time this was just the escape I needed.

Not my favorite Stephanie Plum volume. Stephanie lacks her usual sass - it's almost as if she is depressed, or at least at a point in her life when she is questioning who she is and is meant to be. Filled with the typical car wrecks (although these are quite imaginative), the plot is otherwise uneventful.

At this point, I certainly know what to expect with a Stephanie Plum novel. This one was par for the course. As all my favorite Stephanie Plum novels do, it had plenty of Grandma, Lula, and Ranger. It was light on Morelli, and I could say I want her to just choose already but would miss the other guy in future books. There were some fun side characters. 27 books in... if you know, you know.

I have been looking forward to this release for months. I am hoping with a new publisher, editor, and naming convention that the series gets a bit of a refresh since the last few books started to get a bit repetitive.

It wouldn't be a Stephanie Plum novel without multiple cars being destroyed- including Ranger's 911-buildings blowing up, funerals, and someone wanting to kidnap Stephanie and Grandma. The hunt for the treasure continues, but will it be found? Entertaining as always.

Three verdicts are available to Scottish juries: Guilty, Not Guilty and Not Proven. The last one has been derided as 'not guilty but don't do it again' but it is grammatically superior. A criminal case is either proven beyond reasonable doubt or it is not.

The Law of Innocence is a timely, fast-moving murder tale from one of the master storytellers, Michael Connelly.

Mickey Haller, famed criminal defense attorney, suddenly finds himself framed for killing a former client. With no idea as to who would go to the trouble of constructing a seemingly slam dunk case against him or why, members of his office staff and family members past and present band together to help him. Connelly is a pro, and he never seems to write a bad book (except for Chasing the Dime, which I just couldn't get into). He begins here with a solid premise, Mickey Haller, the Lincoln Lawyer, has been arrested after the cops discover a dead body in the trunk of his Lincoln. He's going to defend himself, of course, and he's going to have to organize his own defense while locked up and under threat from other prisoners and even the guards.

I‚Äôm in increasing awe at Michael Connelly‚Äôs books. They grab you and YOU then cling on for dear life. This latest is no exception. Mickey Haller is in deep do-do and has to use all his wits (and his family) to extricate himself. The plot is so realistic and Connelly‚Äôs attention to detail is unsurpassed. The gentle weaving of the new ‚Äúvirus from China‚Äù is smart. 6 out of 5 from me for this astonishing read.

To say this is a typical Connelly novel is no bad thing. He crafts a plot like a Swiss watch and the main characters are heroic without being superheroes or cartoonish. These books are so great -- I can hardly put them down. Michael Connelly Scores Again

With ‚ÄúThe Law of Innocence‚Äù Michael Connelly‚Äôs Lincoln-Lawyer series achieves the near impossible: lawyer Mickey Haller‚Äôs life becomes more compelling than that of his half-brother (retired) LAPD detective Harry Bosch. For years, the Harry Bosch series has been the police-procedural gold standard. With ‚ÄúThe Law of Innocence‚Äù the Mickey Haller series has edged into first place.

Tight and taut

Dear Mr. Connelly,
Thank you for delivering me from the daily stress of living through the most heinous time of my life. To everyone else this is a fast paced legal thriller that is worth reading slowly, otherwise you'll be back to worrying if you're going to live to read the next one. Already I'm anxious the characters involved haven't seen the serious dilemma they now have from the pandemic and the buffoon refusing to code the election. Wear your mask!

I thought the book was pretty juvenile. More importantly, Connelly is going to discover, like ESPN, the NFL and the NBA discovered, that people do not want politics mixed in with whatever they do to escape politics. I am taking him off my list of authors to follow. I will miss Bosch but that is the way it works. If Connelly cannot learn this lesson instinctively, maybe the 72 million people who voted for the man he characterizes as a liar can convince him.

Not worth the wait (7 years!)

Not quite 3 stars because of the ending. Would be 3 stars if some major character got covid - that would make it more interesting.

A few returning characters do seem thrown in just to toss us a few bones, and Haller‚Äôs relationships seem predictable, but his quest to prove his innocence is exciting and Connelly‚Äôs skillfully quick inclusion of COVID‚Äôs arrival in the US adds another uneasy race against the clock for Haller.

Micky Haller the famous defense attorney finds himself in jail on trial for murder- there's a dead man in the trunk of his Lincoln Lawyer ride.
