Tight, well-paced, excellent

One of Connelly's recent novels left me thinking maybe he was spreading himself too thin, but he has come roaring back with this page- turner! I stayed up all night and read through to the twisty, turny exciting end. I will continue to pre-order anything Michael Connelly writes!

Michael Connelly would just like to remind you that he can write courtroom dramas with the big rep boys, Grisham, Turow, whomever, and leave them in the dust. All the regulars are here as Mickey defends himself against a murder charge. Four hundred odd pages but you'll finish it fast, you won't be able to help yourself.

Fresh from the oven, feels so good to read it so soon after publication!

I was really missing Mickey Haller and Connelly has listened to us readers. The plot is good, the courtroom sequences are fun to read. The personal drama was on point, I really love Maggie and Hayley. I wish there was more of Bosch, but I'm gonna take what I get.

Overall, a fun book to read.

There's a downside to reading a Michael Connelly novel: It's like sitting down to a scrumptious fudge sundae. Each spoonful is a delight yet, with each spoonful, you realize that it is one less remaining. It's a kind of a "good-news-bad-news" metaphor. Now all I can do is twiddle my thumbs awaiting his next creation.

Well, Mickey Haller, the Lincoln Lawyer, is in very deep doody in this one. He's on trial for murder.
That's all I'm gonna reveal plotwise. Again, Mr. Connelly proves himself more than capable in carrying a story to exciting peaks all the way through by immersing us in legal battles and personal challenges. And McFierce is back in the fold, maybe.

I just finished this book an hour ago. It‚Äôs a wild ride and a good read. It‚Äôs suspenseful but it‚Äôs not the usual Mickey Haller book‚ÄîMickey pulling a win out of the air at the last moment in a courtroom. In fact, it left me a bit sad because it actually seems like it may be a final Mickey Haller book. If so, he ties up a lot of loose ends and puts Mickey‚Äôs life in order in a happy way.

I have enjoyed connellys books over the years, I have read near all his books. I was appaled at his gratuitously, stupid remarks about the Trump administation and the GOP and Fox news, How did he expect those sappy remarks to make the book better? Im sure there are more appropriate ways to vent his left wing rantings. (right on Michael)

The Law of Innocence is an exceptionally well-crafted, legal, action drama that keeps moving towards some heart-warming courtroom battles. Anyone who enjoys dueling lawyers with sharp arguments and with a good personality judge in between is likely to love this novel. I wish the author had spent some more time on an equally deserving and uplifting denouement, even if along the predictable lines.

Boring and unauthentic

Connelly should stick with Harry Bosch. If this book is supposed to be a legal thriller, it missed the mark big time. Haller is on trial for murder with life in prison at stake and he‚Äôs more concerned with tricking the prosecution than finding out who really committed the murder.

Connelly never disappoints. ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è Michael Connelly has been my favorite detective novel author for years. I have read and own every single one of his books and wait each year for the next one to arrive. I love him even more with his new book, where he gives zero f*cks if he looses readers, with his not so subtle slams of Trump. ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

Excellent narration, as always. This was another excellent installment of the Harry Bosch Universe. This particular book focuses on Mickey Haller but we do see a lot of characters from previous books. I also enjoyed that this book threw in a small plot line that included the start of the pandemic. I adore Michael Connelly books!

LOVED This book. I‚Äôve read everything Michael Connolly has ever written and this just might be his best book yet. Where Harry Bosh (plays a minor part in this book) is getting up and years and not so exciting, Mickey Haller is really a fun character. Good action and it keeps you on the edge of your seat till the last page ‚Äì great read!

Rounded up to 3 stars.

I enjoyed the little we saw of Harry Bosch, and the ever-evolving relationship with Maggie McFierce. The judge was an enjoyable character, too.

And while the idea of the case was a good one, the case details and courtroom presentation seemed a little lacklustre.

I always enjoy Michael Connelly's books - this one a little less so than most.

Connelly is a really great writer - this latest Mickey Haller story sees him defending himself from a murder charge after a body is discovered in the boot of his car. I particularly love the courtroom action in these books, with the strategy and tactics and nuances of cross-examination. A great read - all in one sitting.

Michael Connelly delivers again. Lincoln Lawyer Mickey Haller returns in this fast-paced thriller. It‚Äôs all hands on deck as Haller defends himself from a murder charge and even gets assists from half-brother Harry Bosch and ex-wife Maggie McFierce. Connelly long ago cemented his status as a master story teller. This book just adds to the legend.

Guilty - Almost

Connellys books are so well written you just cruise through them and go with the flow of the story line. the story is good and keeps you interested the entire time. You really learn to hate the prosecutor as you get into the book. Who said trials were fair - hardly. You will enjoy this story.

Katie Sise has outdone herself with OPEN HOUSE, her latest ingenious addition to the world of domestic suspense. A sly, stirring whodunnit with an ending that‚Äôs nothing short of perfection. A must read!

user_name: PinkAmy loves books, cats and naps
review_text: Another month, another below average Amazon Prime First Reads book. The premise sounded interesting, but OPEN HOUSE lacked originality and characters or even a victim I cared about.

Gripping and nail-biting, this one garnered my whole-hearted involvement from the first word to the last, leaving me no option but to read it in one sitting. Thanks to the Amazon Firsts program, otherwise this enthralling book wouldn‚Äôt have come my way.

Emma McCullough vanished from a college party in the woods by the river when she was just twenty-one. Ten years later her case is still unsolved, until her bracelet is found and the police are active on the case once again.

The story is told from t
Sise is smart - she had me confident I had solved this whodunnit more than once while reading, only to reroute my mind. Open House captivates, I just HAD to know. Seamless ending does not disappoint.
Loved Open House! Full of suspense until the very end. Definitely worth the read!

How had Haley never thought of this before? - Chapter 53

I highlighted the above quote in my Kindle with the comment, "Goooooood fucking question." I had figured out that little revelation twenty chapters earlier. Open House is a mystery novel, unfortunately it's a mystery novel that telegraphs its red herrings and twists so obviously that you can pretty easily infer the truth just by looking at the gap that's left.

Split between two timelines, Open House traces the story of two sisters. Haley, in

‚ÄùHow is anyone supposed to know who the good ones are? Maybe there‚Äôs not even such a thing as good; maybe there are only shades of gray and circumstances and people reacting to them in myriad ways. Maybe no one should be surprised by anything anyone does. Maybe we‚Äôre all just animals trying to survive.‚Äù

Ten years ago, Haley‚Äôs older sister Emma walked into the woods near her university campus and vanished. No reason was ever given and she was never heard from again. Fast forward to the present

True mystery book with unexpected twists and turns.

I am an avid reader. From the moment I began this book, I did not put it down until I was through reading it in its entirety. Katie has created a story with wonderful, fully developed characters. Their stories of life interconnecting in ways that are continuously being revealed to the reader. I felt the emotions of the characters as the author intended for me to. Being as the story revolves around the unsolved mystery of a tragic death and the d

Excellent writing. I liked it. I didn't love it. Decent Plot with so-so pacing.

OPEN HOUSE is an extremely intimate look at the emotional fallout that takes place when a loved one goes missing without any resolution, for any period of time.  Experts talk about resolution and closure, which seem to require either confirmation of death or reasonable expectation (or even proof) of life.

As OPEN HOUSE  begins, Hanah and her folks have been living in anguish for ten long years, since the disappearance

I received this novel from the Amazon First Reads program. I thought the author had an interesting plot-a sister's disappearance, presumed dead, several characters. There was something else a.... I can't tell you without spoiling the story. Both plot points have potential. What I did not like was the slow start. I was not interested until I was 47% in. I got stuck on one of the characters, the one who chose to go to Stanford but did not come across as an excellent student. I envision a senior wh

I read "We Were Mothers" by this author (also a Kindle First book) awhile back, and though I didn't love it, it was better than this book.

Told through the POV of three women: Haley and Priya in present day, and Emma 10 years prior before she disappeared. Haley was so weird, I didn't get her character at all. I kept waiting for some kind of explanation of why she was so robotic, but there was none. Priya seemed to have some mental health issues that magically went away at the conclusion of the bo

A quiet suburban town holds many dark secrets despite its peaceful facade. Ten years ago Haley‚Äôs sister Emma disappeared and to this day her body hasn‚Äôt been recovered. Some believed it was a suicide; some speculated that she had simply run off; some, including Haley‚Äôs father, nurse a hope that Emma may still be alive. But now that Emma‚Äôs bracelet is found and the old investigation is reopened, will the police be able to bring the truth to light or will Emma‚Äôs fate remain unknown forever?

I real

I love a good mystery. Since last year I‚Äôve been on a thriller kick. Seizing the darkness in life through the pages of a book and hanging on tight.

This book was among the amazon free reads for the month of November. Sounded interesting and got consistently good reviews.

The novel is told in the point of view of three people. Haley, Priya, and Emma.
Haley‚Äôs big sister Emma disappeared one night from a party in the woods. A decade later new evidence is found that reopens Emma‚Äôs case. Most people

Wow!

I seldom give a book 5 stars but this one blew me away. It is very well written and drew me in from the beginning. Emma McCullough was a university student when she disappeared one winter night. Ten years later a bracelet belonging to Emma has been found at the bottom of a river gorge and the circumstances surrounding her disappearance are once again being investigated. The story moves back and forth between present day accounts and narrative from 10 years previously, told in first person by

"Open House" definitely didn't do it for me. The plot, as far as I got into the book (I read about 60%), revolves around the disappearance of a college student, Emily and ten years afterwards the non fatal stabbing of her college room mate Josie. Haley, Emily's younger sister, is the main character in the book. Chapters jump around timeframes, and viewpoints of various characters. I found it somewhat confusing, even with guides at the head of each chapter indicating the present or past, and whic

I liked this book; I didn't love it. The book bounces back and forth from 10 years ago to the present and is told from the perspective of four separate characters. With seven main characters, I didn't really care for any of them and, particularly, not the victim. (Just an note - When I was the age of the characters way back in the 60s, we were all aware of, and regularly used, birth control if we were sexually active. If the dozens of books I've read is any indication, no one seems to know about

A tale of secrets and whodunit after the disappearance of art student Emma McCullough in a sleepy university town. Ten years later, the discovery of new evidence brings all the trauma back to the surface in the lives of those closest to Emma as slowly and dramatically the truth comes out. Will anyone's lives remain intact after the fallout?

An easy and interesting read. Content: Although illicit actions are alluded to, there are no sex scenes or foul language. Drinking and drugs are referred to,

A book full of women who seem to have a lot of self-doubt and men who make terrible decisions. Some of them (people and decisions) are interesting. Many characters are in relationships that seem troubled and/or full of questionable aspects. Haley- is she supposed to be traumatized or is it being suggested that she is autistic with the references to being unable to make eye contact?

This book is like pieces of several puzzles mixed up and it doesn't really come together, even in an accidental way

This was my Amazon First Read for November! This book comes out on 12/1. The plot piqued my interest and it ended up being...fine. It didn‚Äôt blow my socks off, but it‚Äôs well-written and was easy and fun to binge read. The thing is though, it almost needs to be binge read, particularly in one sitting, because once I put it down for the night, it was super difficult to motivate myself to pick it back up in the morning. But I did like the alternating POV chapters and the fact that they flipped from

The Spiral Kept Tightening

Simply put: this book was amazing.

I have so much more to say, but I think I need a little while longer to properly process it and put it all into words. And a solid six to eight hours of unconsciousness, since I devoured this book when I should have been sleeping!

Excellent choice as a Amazon Prime Reads. I highly recommend it to anyone that likes to be caught up in a spiral with each pass becoming tighter and tighter before finally reaching the end.

I'm not sure what genre this book is supposed to be classified as, mystery/suspense? It is a mystery but it isn't suspenseful. The mystery is light and I had no trouble figuring the whole thing out. That's unusual for me. I typically can't figure out a mystery and don't even try.

The author created a tight cast of characters (just three couples) so there was a smaller group to keep track of. The characters are what held the story together. They were interesting and I cared about their relationsh

Amazon Early Reads meant I got this book for free and I did enjoy it but I wasn‚Äôt totally taken with it. The are some plus points, particularly the twists at the end are captivating and I do have a sense of relief it wasn‚Äôt as straight forward as if feared.

The drawbacks are the middle is too long, too much filler and I really didn‚Äôt empathise with the victim she was quite unlikeable whereas some of the other characters we probably weren‚Äôt supposed to like as much seemed much more appealing.

Over

I received this book through the First Reads program. The book definitely had potential. Unfortunately, the characters fell flat for me. I appreciated that it kept me guessing but it was really slow to start, as others have mentioned. I am the type of reader that has to finish a story, unless I just can‚Äôt. Once it picked up the pace, it was a much better book. I would give this author another shot. Maybe some better character development would help. It was hard to have the needed empathy, for th

Need notes

Maybe it is the aging process or the fact I read so many books as well as listening to one of two at a time but I had a hard time keeping the characters straight. I think I should have kept notes of who went with whom. I did like the story line and the intrigue. I would have liked an ending that was a little more fleshed out. I feel like I missed a little something. I do have many distractions as we all do so that may be a part.

Cold Case

An intriguing case of how the sins of youth and the past can and do often come to light unexpectedly especially with advances in forensics. The characters involved have varied entanglements unknown to each other, oh what a tangled web of deceit. The main character is interesting with complicated relationships the who done it goes through many changes and the end well see if you work it out.

No winners!

This was an incredible book about loss. How long do you look for a missing loved one. How long can one family carry that kind of pain. And every one had secrets. This crime could have been solved if anyone has the courage to step up. In the end everyone lost. But a family finally had answers. Very compelling read. The real culprit was a surprise. You won't want to put it down.

Open House

This is a book about college friends and dark secrets. While I did enjoy the book I found it hard to follow the characters, which is unusual for me. The plot is interesting and follows the friends after one of them comes up missing. How and why should is missing is the mystery, which is solved by the end of the book, while exposing the weakness and character flaws of the members of the group and finally see them get appropriate rewards for their deeds..

points deducted for prologue. so much narration instead of dialogue
its disturbing how much narration instead of dialogue.
example:
'A barista called out a drink order, and Haley tried to pull herself from her thoughts. She thanked Josie and Noah for the coffee and took a sip, forcing a smile as they watched her.'
didn‚Äôt get really interesting until 73%.
and the ending just sort of wasn‚Äôt worth all the build-up, for me.

This book really showed what happens when booze, drugs and hormones are interacting all at the same time. Nothing good ever happens. Parents of teens should read this, but then they'd lock their kids in a room until they're 25 or more.

The writing is excellent and kept my attention to the very end.

Really good read!

This book held my interest from the first page. Switching between past and present can sometimes be confusing, but it was integral to this story. Halfway thru, still hadn't figured out who did it. I found the underlying theme of what makes a family compelling and realistic.

Will look for other books by this author!

This book really showed what happens when booze, drugs and hormones are interacting all at the same time. Nothing good ever happens. Parents of teens should read this, but then they'd lock their kids in a room until they're 25 or more.

The writing is excellent and kept my attention to the very end.

Really good read!

This book held my interest from the first page. Switching between past and present can sometimes be confusing, but it was integral to this story. Halfway thru, still hadn't figured out who did it. I found the underlying theme of what makes a family compelling and realistic.

Will look for other books by this author!

Mystery, intriguing, page turner

Ten years ago, Emma disappeared and the police classified it as a suicide jump off of a high cliff into the water. Her parents and sister didn‚Äôt believe she killed herself. Now, after ten years, new evidence comes to light that will change things and many people‚Äôs lives Very good, suspenseful story.

Everything did not go as I expected, which was good (of course I guessed so of it, as you do, but there were some unexpected things). But it was also believable, set up well, and didn't go off the deep end. I also liked the ending for the main character, Haley. I was worried at first about how she would be handled.

Meh. It was mildly entertaining. It had elements to make it a compelling read: jealously, the coming of age young adults, illicit love affairs, dark dangerous places in the woods, and intrigue. But for me, it all fell flat. I'm glad it was a freebie from Amazon Prime First Reads - and not something that I actually paid for. ;)

Something missing

I had a difficult time getting engaged with the story initially but pushed through anyway. Unfortunately I never liked any of the characters given all seemed a bit stunted emotionally to the point of overboard. I felt badly for this incestual group of people who never really lived their life. Too depressing for an escape read

I tried

Can't put my to finger on it and I did try hard to get into this story. I tried to be interested. But I just found a very few parts that intrigued me. The back and forth, the petty jealousy, the secrets, the lies, the backstabbing, and the whole group dynamics was all to hard to find likable characters.

It's a fairly short thriller at 255 pages and it has a tight mystery at it's heart that will keep you guessing. I finished all within a day; it's easy to read and intriguing to keep you going. You can sense something's off with some of these characters but it's never too much to give the game away too soon. A great little who-dunnit.

What a great mystery! The summary of this book did it no justice. I never thought that I would be so engrossed in it as I was. It was a clean mystery without explicit sex and it was well written. You go back and forth between past and present, but it's not confusing and laid out very well. I can't get the word, "but wouldn't it be better if you weren't" out of my head! This is a must read.

Such a surprisingly good read! The dual timeline was fantastic to bring all the characters to life. Thoroughly enjoyed the intrigue and anticipation of learning the truth. SO much to process - family love, friendship love and relationship love. Where is the line? What is trust built upon? What happens when everything changes? So, so good!

Great Read.

I can‚Äôt wait to recommend it to everyone I know. I rarely come across a book that I tell other people to read....but this is it. I also
usually figure out the ending before I get there.....this one I didn‚Äôt.
I loved it and will be reading We Were Mothers by Katie Sise next!

Open House by Katie Sise

This is a very well plotted, well written book. It is told in many differing POVs with the flashbacks unraveling the mysterious death even as it was being solved 10 years later. This is my first read from Sise, but it will not be my last. (In my head, I will alter the ending just a tad.)

Good story, but drags in places

Open house as my pick for the Amazon First Reads is a story that goes back and forth between two time periods 10 years apart.trying to solve the murder of the sister of one of the characters. There are interesting characters and enough twists to keep the reader interested in solving the mystery. I hope to read the other book by this author soon.

Haley‚Äôs sister disappeared 10 years ago at a party in college, and Haley is now mixed up in the lives of those who knew her sister best as she tries to unravel what happened that night. Some of it (the actions of the police) seemed pretty unbelievable, but it wasn‚Äôt enough to keep me from enjoying the mystery.

I found the characters in Open House to lack substance. They all seemed to be rather flat. Particularly all of the men appeared to be the same person. I never got to know them or relate to them.
Even the two main characters, one dead and one living, never really became real to me.
The ending was good as far as the plot went and this was the only time I related to any of the characters.

Just Enough

This book had just enough energy in it that I I finished it. The constant flipping back and forth made it annoying. Just as it got into a groove with a story line it jumps back ten years. Then back ahead again. Required a lot to finish it but did have somewhat of a surprise ending. Kudos for that.

Ok, but nothing particularly special. The jumping around of characters, along with the forward and backwards time in motion, just didn‚Äôt help with the flow of the story line. But rather it all felt a bit haphazard and convoluted. So this book passed the time of day for me, but wouldn‚Äôt be a recommendation.

Small town murder

Well written and thought provoking novel that kept this reader captured. Ten years is a lifetime to have closure for the death of Haleys' sister Emma. Many interesting suspects added to the mystery.

Ok

I received this book as part of Amazon First reads. This book skips around between now and 10 years ago sometimes it is a little confused. I like the story about a sister's love but for me the end of the book fell apart.

Open house

I usually don‚Äôt care for reading books that are presence tense then back ten years or so but this one worked for me. I loved the tale, characters, and how each twist and turn gave more insight, the climax was superb and ending perfect. Thanks for a great read

Moving Story with lots of Twists and Turns

This story is about sisters and what one sister is willing to do to find out what happened to the other. It‚Äôs about relationships...lies...and so much more!! Loved this book!!!

Good Story

I really enjoyed this story. I did have a little trouble keeping the couples straight since they all had intermingled relationships. I kept changing my mind about who the 'bad"guys were,so it was good mystery

Couldn't put it down.

I had a tough time doing my motherly duties these past few days because I just wanted to sit and read. I love that you get both of the sisters point of view in the story. I also really loved the sisterly bond. The ending was satisfying and real. Great job.

disappointed

It started off well, but it was pretty obvious from the beginning who the guilty person was. There were too many coincidences that were not believable. It was an easy read but not a must keep reading, gripping page turner.

.Not for me

I had a hard time getting into this story. I understood the main point, it it was boring to me. I skipped to th last five chapters, and I do not feel I missed much. I learned the murder and why.

I received this book from Prime First Reads. I didn't think the writing was very good. It is an average story that bounces around from past to present. By the time it was finally over I didn't care who did it.

I received this as a Prime First Read pick. The writing is rather poor. The story is a typical modern mystery that goes back and forth in time between three or four people. I figured out who done it, but by the time I finished it, I didn't really care. Puzzled by the high ratings.

Well written

This was a well paced story, it kept my interest, was well written. Just when you think you know who killed Emma there's extra information to make you rethink your conclusion. Could say more but not without spoilers ;)

The truth sets you free

A mystery that is also a study of family trauma, how the secrets of the past twist and skew the present. Even though I typically read action-oriented mysteries, I found myself drawn into the dynamics of grief, guilt and silence. Highly recommended.

Execelent

LOVED IT! You kept me guessing who done it, till the very end!
No other book did that for me. I pretty much always guess who it is.
Very interesting till the end. Thank you!

Good build up!

Great story telling with a twisty plot. Ending was a bit abrupt and kind of bittersweet but to be expected with the circumstances that played out. All in all, a pretty good mystery read.

Couldn't stop reading this one!!

Very suspenseful!! Couldn't put this away till I read the whole book. Kept my interest pretty well. Who you thought was the perpetrator didn't turn out to be whom it seemed. If you're into this type of novel this is for you!!

An easy read if you like murder mysteries. It started off a little slow but quickly pulled me in. Although I guessed parts of the outcome, it still came with a few surprises at the end I did not see coming. A nice book for a rainy day.

Amazon‚Äôs Prime First Read. The plot sounded decent but the book fell flat. Too many characters and not enough focus on any one of them to be able to relate. Typical whodunnit with everyone sleeping with everyone else at some point over the 10 year span.

Great mystery

Suicide? Murder? An accidental death? Ten years have passes since Emma disappeared. So many possibilities of who did what and when. You won't be able to put this down.

I like the story- of course because it is a mystery you always have to figure it out before the end and I correctly guessed but there were some twists. I didn't expect the ending to be what it is either. I like that the main character has some quirks and the flashback between times is smooth.

Mysterious Death

Many twists & and turns in this haunting mystery. Just when you think you have a clue something happens to prove you are wrong. Often felt frustrated with the many confusing roles of the characters.

Lots of twists

I received this book from Amazon First Reads. At first it didn't catch me and I thought meh but then I was quickly hooked and finished the book in 1 day. It was an enjoyable read with lots of twists and red herrings. I'd be interested to read more from the author.

Pretty good read. I thought a little bit of character development was lacking for two of the characters but overall a great and interesting read. Never read this author before. Happy to have found her.

Well written

This hits so many checkouts in items making a good book" " plotting, characters, setting. This author delivers and also shared s deeper truth about the love of a sister.

Surprising Ending

I found myself having trouble keeping the characters and the story line straight as the author moved back and forth between decades and characters.. But even so, i was surprised by the ending, which is why I gave the book four stars instead of three.

Open House was a good, quick read with a few twists and turns. It is very similar to several other popular books in this genre. So much so that I often felt that I had read this book before. But still, an enjoyable read.

I didn't really enjoy the book or the characters, but the ending was clever and made the book worth finishing. I can't quite figure out why every single character was so unlikeable, even the traumatized "kid sister," and even the victim, but they were.

A Real Page-turner

Tons of twists in this mystery! So often in suspense novels, once the mystery is explained, there are still about 40 pages to go. This book kept it interesting until the very end.

New 1st read book

It was a great read 1st time from this author, it was my free book for the month. It kept me reading and engaged. I thought about the characters when not reading the book so it became real.

Great book that I couldn't put down

Really enjoyed this book as lots of twists and turns that kept you hooked. Enjoyed the way the story was told from different character's perspectives. When it was reaching the final scenes i was gripped and totally involved in the story.

Keeps twisting until the end

This book was a slow start for me but once the character development was over I couldn't stop reading. All the cover ups and twists really go until the very end. Each time you think you've figured it out, you haven't. This was a great book.

Suspenseful

Kept my interest. All the way through the book. A little slow in the beginning but picked up pace as I read on. Would recommend to my sister as we trade off books all the time.

Well written

A thrilling story about family and friends. College friends and jealousy. Ten years have gone by an Emma is believed dead but what happened to her. Full of mystery and intrigue.

Unexpected emotional hits

Wow. The author‚Äôs expression of Haley‚Äôs grief at the loss of Emma was at times breathtaking. Such a vivid illustration of grief and the scars an unexpected loss can leave.
I hope we‚Äôll get to see more of Haley in the future!

Intriguing and fresh

Great read. The switching points of view kept it very fresh as plot development kept me on my toes throughout. I honestly thought I had figured out the mystery a couple different times and was wrong up until the very end.
It was a good fast read. It took some unexpected turns. Overall I enjoyed the book.
Good mystery - didn‚Äôt figure it out

Loved it!

This book held my attention from start to finish. I loved how it flowed so effortless. Never read this author before but I‚Äôll definitely read more of her work.
Started a bit slow but fun read.
Lots of twist and turns in the plot up to the last pages.
Engaging story, keeps you guessing. Easy read for a rainy day. Not a lot of character depth but well written.
4.5 ‚≠êÔ∏è great whodunnit. Twists and turns til the very end.
What a fascinating roller coaster of a story! The way the author divided up the past and the present did a great job of increasing the suspense and I really had no idea how it was going to end.

Good book but predictable

I liked this book just fine. I had been reading some really disturbing thrillers so a nice predictable who done it was nice.

Good Read

I enjoyed this book I liked the characters and the twists. Good story and recommend for a fast read. Few surprises which I liked.

Excellent

I chose this rating because this is an excellent book, with the twist and turns that keep you guessing until the end.
Another excellent book by this author! Thoroughly engrossing from beginning to end. I stayed up until well after 4am to finish it! And there was a twist I never saw coming.
Great book with plenty of twists and turns

Interesting

Mediocre. Probably just me but I had a difficult time keeping up with the characters. Who liked who, who is related, etc.

This book, the first in a series, was an Amazon First Reads choice that looked intriguing. And you know what? It is. Not only did I enjoy it thoroughly, but I'm now looking forward to the next one.

To be sure, it's on the grisly side; FBI Special Agent Nina Guerrera was the victim of almost unspeakable acts done by a serial killer/rapist back when she was 16. She turned out to be the one who got away - but not without a ton of physical and emotional scars. As this book begins, she's jogging on a

THE CIPHER Puts A Modern Twist On The Serial Killer Trope

Following the success of her Veranda Cruz series, author Isabella Maldonado introduces us to her latest heroine, FBI Special Agent Nina Guerrera, in her upcoming mystery thriller, The Cipher.

As a teenager, Nina managed to escape from a serial killer who was never captured. Years later, Nina has built a career with the FBI. But when a failed assault involving Nina is caught on video and goes viral on the internet, the serial killer takes no

In this new series, author Maldonado brings a sense of authenticity that one rarely finds in police procedural thrillers. I am sure this is because she is the real deal. Her experience as a police officer should and does bring a real sense that she knows of what she speaks. But that has little to do with literary talent and this is where she shines. The book is real page-turner. It is filled with many memorable characters but it is the heroine, Nina Guerrera, who comes alive in a memorable way.

My Amazon First Reads selection for October, The Cipher was an enjoyable piece of crime fiction. Our primary character, Nina, is tough as nails and sigh of relief from the usual protrayal of ditzy female agents. The remaining characters are typical agents but with a biting humor and a great use of word play. One can tell that the author has experience, her writing is detailed and on point. I highly recommend The Cipher and am looking forward book 2 in the series.

This was my first book from this author. It was a decent read. It reminded alot of a FBI show that just ended criminal minds-was never a big fan of that show lol. The main character was ok-dialogue was ok and the secondary characters were ok . I thought at times it dragged a little bit-and I do not like knowing what the bad guy is doing or thinking, I have said that before. I was not wild about the ending, I saw it coming a mile away. I think it could have been a better book , not sure why just

One of my Kindle First choices of this month......I wasn't especially struck with it as it isn't really anything too unique. A feisty female protagonist with a miserable, abusive past who now takes no nonsense from anyone. She comes up again a killer some years ago and then has a further encounter in the modern-day.....I've read it all before. I enjoyed it well enough and will probably try the next in this series, as I liked her trio of co-workers, especially Breck. So it will be interesting to

Well written thriller

As a former English teacher, I found it refreshing to read a story that flowed seamlessly.
I recommend this book to all mystery, thriller, and police procedure enthusiasts!

If you like strong female characters, this is your book.

A chilling and gripping thriller to start a new series. In some ways it seems like an old idea - a damaged agent, pursued by a ruthless predator while the FBI tries to identify and capture him. I will preface my review to say I am not a reader of murder mysteries or police/law enforcement type books. It just has never been my genre. Yet, I saw this book in first reads and it is possibly the best book I have gotten from this program. Yes, really.

Page turner!

This is the first book of Ms Maldonado 's that I've read. It is an excellent action book with a strong female lead. Nina, out of necessity, became a quick thinking survivor throughout her life. I didn't want to put the book down, the story kept me wanting more. I'm definitely looking forward to the next book in this series!!

This is not a book drawn purely from a writer's imagination. The author's extensive law enforcement background gives it a sense of authenticity that someone without that experience could never accomplish. Unlike those of some authors, Maldonado's heroine is admirably strong, both physically and mentally, without straining her plausibility. I enjoyed this one so much that I'm almost afraid to read the books in her Veranda Cruz series for fear I'll be disappointed.

Great storyline from start to finish!

Good Read

Page turner

Very pleased!

So good

A God. I think not!

Gripping

Great book

Outstanding Writing

Not predictable

Wow!!!

Engrossing

Great read!

Very good book. I was not able to put it down as I could not wait to see whay happened next

Wow!

Well done

Great Story

Great story

FBI agent Guerrera. Good action, good plot, relates well to FBI employees I have known.

Fantastic!

Wow! Couldn't put it down!

My first time...

* Minor spoilers ahead **

On the surface, the premise is nothing original; the marriage between a happily married woman (gorgeous, naturally) and her ambitious, handsome husband (what else could he be? Ugly and poor?) is threatened by a scheming, conniving woman from the wrong side of the tracks.

Cat Winthorpe has it all; money, power, prestige

The ultimate suspense of the year! How well do you know your neighbors? You‚Äôll think twice about dinners and parties. Cat and William have lived a privileged life in Atherton, wealthy community south of SF, and own numerous businesses. Neena and Mark are also successful, with her doctorate degree and his demolition company, however there is just something off about then. Alessandra Torre has become one of my go-to favorite authors. All of the stories I have read of hers suck me in from the first chapter and keep me engaged until the last, savoring the twists and turns she is so adept at laying out.

Every Last Secret is no exception, telling the story of Cat Winthorpe, a young, beautiful women who has it all: The house, the money, the life and a devastatingly handsome husband, William, at her beck and call. She wants for nothing, but as a new employee of William's

The perfect husband (William).
The perfect role within her community.
So, when that perfect life is threatened, how far will she go to maintain that life? That's the question that is explored in this book.

review_text:
Not many books leave me speechless and fulfilled at the same time but Every Last Secret did. It‚Äôs conniving. It pisses you off but it‚Äôs like train wreck you can‚Äôt look away or in this case put your kindle down. When I say it pissed me off I was extremely upset.

I hate Neena. Hate. Her. I don‚Äôt think she has one redeemable quality. Zero. She has a great husband who worships her feet and she treats him like he is mud on her shoe. She‚Äôs as fake as they come and I was hoping she would die the whole

Twisty and interesting

You know what? I actually enjoyed this quite a bit. I wasn't sure that I was liking it in the beginning - none of the characters are particularly likable, the "Real Housewives" vibe wasn't 100% working for me, and I wasn't sure where it was heading. But the writing is strong and there's some compelling element that made me continue reading until all of a sudden I was invested in the story. There are twists and turns, lies, jealousy, cheating, and characters who are shades o

2 couples. 1 story. 1 game. How can you win the game when you don't know who else is playing?

I love a good, unique psychological thriller that pulls me in and leaves me breathless or with my heart pounding with every twist. I was super excited to see that A.R. Torre was going to give us another one. It's been a bit. Every Last Secret was not original, but the pacing and writing was great. The characters kept each other on their toes and beat for beat, the book worked.

Matt and Neena move into the

How am I going to review this? I don‚Äôt even know where to start. This book was everything!! I always enjoy A. Torre‚Äôs suspenseful books and this one just takes the cake. It was a delightful change in the theme of her books. I loved Cat throughout the whole book. She was badass and never backed down from the challenge that was Neena. She was smart and calculated. Call me a snob but I enjoyed every underhanded thing Cat did to Neena. We get one chapter from Williams pov and it single handedly sums

Was this book what I thought it was going to be? No.
Did the cover have anything to do with the story? No.
Did I devour this book in one sitting? Yes.
Did I end up loving every single written word on the pages? Yes.

Honestly, this book was a treat. I haven't read a book that kept me going like this in a long, long time. So to say I loved it would be an understatement.

Did I think it got a little messy along the way, yes. It did. There for a while the plot was just too fast paced and a lot of thi

As someone who doesn't generally like thrillers, this book really had me hooked. The entire time I thought it was going in one direction but it totally caught me off guard near the end. It didn't seem like any details were overlooked or out of place and the main characters were such opposites that my head was constantly reeling, wondering how and where it was going to end. It's not a traditional thriller but if you're like me and want something to introduce you to thrillers or has slightly less

I tore through this book. At some parts, I almost wish I was being watched while reading it, so my facial expressions could have been recorded. The decisions the characters made annoyed me a lot. But by the end, I was turning those electronic pages wanting to see those cookies crumble. Sometimes, in a book like this, you favour one side. Maybe it's the underdog, or maybe its the winner. I didn't see any winners here. And tha

This was a fun, twisty story of two women.

They hate each other but pretend to be friends for the sake of their wealthy neighborhood and husbands. There's Neena who is married to dumpy, boring Matt. And then Cat, married to Neena's boss, William who is smart and gorgeous.

Neena is hell-bent on having an affair with William and she always gets what she wants! The chapters alternate between Neena and Cat's point of view and they are both so deliciously evil.

This is suspense but there's humor too an

I have been reading Ms Torre for years and I especially love it when she writes thrillers and Every Last Secret didn‚Äôt disappoint.

Two women, whilst outwardly looking very different , underneath and behind their own personal facades they were the same. Both strong and determined to Be the best and to get what they wanted - whatever the cost.

To be honest both these women didn‚Äôt appeal to me and I was happy for whichever path the the Author had decides this story should go. But I was intrigued and

Cat and William live the life of luxury and wealth. He owns a company and she tends to the house and social events. So when Neena and her husband move in next door, Cat is initially more than welcoming. But Neena is conniving and will stop at nothing to get what Cat has, including William. Cat is on to her and will do what it takes to keep her perfect life.

Full of secrets, greed and raw emotion. The author did an excellent job setting up the plot and then turning it upside down. A binge worthy r
An incredible thriller that kept me on my toes the whole time. The storyline was exceptional and the characters engaging and believable.

This is a great book to read to escape reality. Very compulsive story writing - I really loved the style. While I‚Äôve read books with a similar storyline in the past, I really enjoyed this book.

She has become my favorite author since the Ghost Writer and she has never disappointed my in anything I‚Äôve read of hers and this book just made me more of a fan.

Good psychological mystery

"Every Last Secret" was an interesting story. Certain aspects were fun because you could see the manipulations & know where they were headed. Certain other aspects were quite surprising and shocking. Throughout none whole book II thought how alike we all are, if our backgrounds are rich or poor. We all have a basic need for love and affection, and insecurities to del with.

So good!

Neena is accustomed to getting what she wants. What she wants this time, is to move up the ladder even higher, more money than she got from her last boss, more social prestige, and even to move into her new boss‚Äôs life. One problem, he‚Äôs married. Oh, two problems, so is she. Neena knows how to play the game to get what she wants, but she may have met her match in Cat, her new boss‚Äôs wife.

This was my first book by Torre and I heard hoe good it was before I read it. Sometimes that's not my favorite thing. Sometimes the books don't exceed my expectations and I'm EVEN more let down. This book, however, was not like that! I adored this book. I was hooked from the very beginning. I couldn't wait to get to the end. the twist was great and even though there were parts I figured out the very end was a pleasant surprise.

3.5 stars

I loved the depth of the characters and how I found myself feeling empathic towards certain ones at different points in the book, and based on some of their actions, that was unexpected.

I figured out the "twist" essentially immediately, as the events were unfolding. There were so many hints scattered throughout the novel, it was hard to miss. Regardless, I was eager to finish the book and enjoyed it overall!

Loved it!!!

I read some of the other reviews, particularly the one star reviews. I understand why they felt the way they did, but I enjoyed this book! You don't have to suspend reality, just understand how underrated and unobserved the crazy was! My heart was pounding waiting too see if Cats' husband would really be that stupid....he was...I enjoyed it alk the way to the end. Definitely recommend

A wicked twisted tale of deceit and jealousy!

This book deserved the five stars and more!! I think I loved this book so much because things happened that I would love to do when faced with it!.
The main characters were Cat, William ,Neema and Matt ,two couples who come into close contact as one person has a plan to change their lives. It's a great book which really fulfilled the storyline perfectly, making the tale absolutely believable.
Highly recommend to everyone!

Money, power, connections, pettiness, vindictiveness, cattiness, and a shitload of ambition to get and keep what one wants, is pretty much the gist of this book. Add in a little sprinkle of unlikeable characters and you have a book where at that point, you can‚Äôt help but want to see how it all plays out.

This was not a bad read, but surely a theme done over and over again. I will say that this was quite the rollercoaster ride with just enough suspense that it was hard to put down.

3.75. I loved Gone Girl. The the domestic suspense genre exploded and there weren't many I liked. This book is definitely more interesting than most. The plot had interesting twists and turns. I knew there'd be a big zag, but I didn't guess it correctly. The ending felt a little soft to me, but otherwise the book was well-constructed. While interesting, I would not describe it as a page-turner.

Develops and twists

This book starts like chick lit, a romantic comedy about two suburban couples, next door neighbors. It progresses into a psychological study, then a psychological thriller, and then a crime scene investigation. I enjoyed the character development. Each of the characters seemed true to life. I really like the Author‚Äôs Note ‚Äî ‚Äúsome of you may hate it; some will love it. If I made you feel something, then I‚Äôve done my job.‚Äù I enjoyed this book.

So I wanted to just read a few pages of this book to get a feel for the story... I ended up ignoring all responsibilities for the day and reading the entire book. I couldn't put it down! Even with having mixed feelings about almost every character, I was invested and needed to know what would happen next. I have never read a book by this author, but I love her writing style and will definitely be looking into her other books!

I didn't know if I'd like this as it had mixed reviews when I saw it on Amazon's First Reads. Plus its not my typical thriller, but I'm so happy I chose it!!! The minute I got into these two adversaries heads I was a goner. Wow!! I loved this story. Its like a delectable soap opera. I always like a good competition between women, especially crazy ones. Its juicy, sexy, and juicy again. I'm going to read this author again for sure. üòÅ

Rising to the top

Neena and Matt are terribly in love and finally move into a fixer upper across the street from Cat and William in a very affluent neighborhood. Neena just so happens to have nailed a job a Motivational Expert for William's firm. When it appears Neena is just a little too needy towards William, Cat is determined to get William on the right track. This Cat and Mouse game gets better and better. What a thriller!

I picked this a my monthly free read from Amazon Prime. I wished I'd kept going. I hate not finishing a book that I've started - but I'm afraid I'm going to with this 1. There is absolutely no story here, im bored after 23 chapters of the same predictable and unrealistic back & forth between Cat & Neenah. It's like a soap opera, boring. At least for me. I gave 2 stars bc I have gotten thru a third - mainly bc i was waiting for the storyline to take off.

It's unusual to have 2 psychopaths in the same story, pitted against each other. I couldn't decide who I liked least Cat or Neena, or William. Matt was the only nice person in the whole story. And, even though I didn't like most of the main characters, it did not take away anything from the story. It kept my interest right up until the end. There were alot of twist and turns, and moved along quick.

Inside every woman married to a successful man, there is a Neena to be feared, and a Cat ready to claw.

This is an exceptionally well written book. Even the flaws or the parts where I asked ‚Äúwhy‚Äù all came together in a stunning conclusion. Every last piece.

I didn‚Äôt expect this to be a book to cause tears to come to the surface, but it most certainly did.

‚ÄúEvery Last Secret‚Äù is page-turning that I absolutely could NOT put down!

This book was one of those I found to be absolutely unputdownable! Torres did an amazing job of developing characters, making a realistic and intriguing plot, in which I got many shocks, thrills, chills, and sometimes even a laugh! Definitely a thriller for those who like revenge on cheaters or even lots of money and jealousy type of books! I highly, highly recommend!
Will make sure to buzz up on all platforms and on release date use my low amazon reviewer number to help review!

Solid 4 stars. While this was predictable by 60% or so, I enjoyed the cat and mouse of it all; the alternate perspectives were also equally compelling. Well developed characters, interesting plot. I'll definitely check out more from this author.

Thanks to Netgalley and the publisher for an ARC in exchange for an honest review.

First, a sincere thank you for sharing the ARC in exchange for an honest review.

This is one of those books with characters so off-putting that you can't help but marvel at their sheer audacity. It's simply beyond the scope. A psychological thrillers that's well written enough to be riveting and with characters you love to hate a la Gone Girl, then there's that ending...Dig it!

This fun romp was filled with unlikable characters and good storytelling. I have enjoyed every Alessandra Torre book I've read.
Although this still didn't surpass my favourite of hers (The Girl in 6e), this was still a solid addition to her body of work.
Please write more mystery/thrillers, I love them so!

4.5 stars. This book was unexpected (in a good way) and something I‚Äôve never read before!
The beginning was a little slow, but more and more things kept happening and I was wondering what would happen next and what was true or false.
At some points I hated some characters and then it would change. I really enjoyed this book!!

Fast-paced, kept me interested. All of the characters are flawed, with none I really liked, but I also didn‚Äôt hate all of them (looking at you, Gone Girl). I wanted to see what happened, what the twists would be, how it would all play out. Not as twisty as I thought it would be, more like a runaway train- you basically know what‚Äôs happening, but you can‚Äôt look away.

This book was so good, I finished it in a day and a half. I LOVE when Alessandra writes suspense. She is so great at the steamy romances that I sometimes forget what an amazing suspense writer she is. This book had me love and hate all the character. I love how once you think you know someone, they are not what they seem. ;-)

So Twisted and Delicious!!!

This story was phenomenal!!! So twisted and delicious!!! At one point I hated every single character, then loved them, felt sorry for them, hated one, love the rest, loved one, hated the rest...it was an absolute roller coaster of a story and very bit of it was incredible!!!

Another phenomenal book by this author who is definitely one of my absolute favourites ..... They do say that 'hell hath no fury' and this is certainly true of Cat in this book - although I have to say that I'm not sure the guy was actually worth fighting for in the first place .... the fight was however very innovative and entertaining. Highly recommended read.

Such a great book - I devoured it quickly! I loved how the chapters switched perspectives and how the layers were slowly pealed back toward the end. It really kept me guessing and I enjoyed every surprise. To those who enjoyed this book and it was their first read of A.R. Torre, I highly recommend the Deanna Madden series.

Rarely do I finish a book in two days, but this one was a page turner. Addicting from the first page, this book includes two Type A women battling it out for the same Type A guy. The women are equally ruthless and cunning and keep you wanting to read more and more. Was sad to get to the last page so quickly.

Cat Winthorpe has it all. Money, friends and a husband who worships her. Until one day he hires a woman to troubleshoot the turbulence between the employees and ease tension in the office. Neena may have everyone else fooled, but Cat in on to her. As she feels the life she loves slipping through her fingers she realizes she will have to fight dirty and with every tool she poses, for she will not loose. Neena thinks she has the upper hand and savors every minute of her hostile take over of everyt

Good quick book

If you are looking for 6 easy pieces, this is not your book. But if you are looking for a quick read through characters that are not very surprising, yet still somewhat unpredictable, this fits. Nice twist at the end, which is telegraphed, but still is mostly satisfying.

Not my normal sort of book tend to stay away from American stories especially ones featuring the ultra rich people in this book but it fast drew me in.
Cat would, and did, do absolutely anything to keep William and the life she had got for herself. Neena never stood a chance despite her well laid plans.
Well worth sticking with.

Secrets Can Destroy

This book starts out with secrets. Secrets of an affair, of something in the past, of neighbors next door.

The middle of the book seemed little long. It seemed to drag on for an while, feeling on to much unnecessary detail.

But keep going. It's worth it to reach the end. Because more secrets are revealed. Surprise secrets.

This book was such an unexpected twist of events. I honestly found myself addicted to the characters & storyline; I couldn't put it down. I initially chose to read it as a fast one just to add on to my book challenge for the year, but it pleasantly surprised me & I am glad I chose to give it a go. I plan on reading more from this author; great writing!

What a Rollercoaster!

This is the best psychological thriller I've ever read, and I've read hundreds of them.
The story is so twisted. The characters felt so real and raw.
I don't even have the words to describe how much I loved this book.
You will not be disappointed with this one!

2.5 stars.

Terrific series made up entirely of novellas from Melinda Leigh and Kendra Elliot writing every other book. I love both authors; however, not so certain I like the format of novellas, nor the long time in between each book. But, I will read anything written by these authors.

Just another day at the office? Not on the atmospheric Widow's Island. A series of well-developed, novella-length, thrilling romantic suspenses. Set in a remote location where natural beauty, folklore, and quirky locals are the backdrop, these tales deliver on riveting plot, complex characters, and engaging relationships. Authors and narrator always bring the listener along for a fabulous story every time.

Short, quick-read novella (or a long short story) with many characters. Not a stand-alone.

Very good ninety-page story with a solid murder plot, interesting subplots, and several very red herrings. A domestic subplot features (another) female dementia patient‚Äîwho seem to be the problem du jour, similar to Asperger syndrome during the Aughts. I really love this series. The main characters Logan Wilde and Tessa Black are interesting and flawed. Each has a strong commitment to their community. Logan is dealing with his PTSD and doing well. Tessa is caring for her teenage sister, Patience, and her mom who has dementia. She leads a very complicated life and feels she is responsible for the whole island. When Tessa is called to a neighborhood where and explosion my have occurred, she finds a dead body. It is a missing foster child reporte

Suspenseful and sweet

An interesting blend of the suspense through the case and sweet through the romance. This is a fantastic series where the characters and the community, as well as the landscape, have come to life through the different books and stories. Tessa and Logan are great individually and as a couple. Their strengths and humor, as well as tougher areas, really showed in this story.

I do recommend reading this series in order as each story built off the next in terms of individual and

Another Great Book

I discovered Melinda Leigh and Kendra Elliott as authors after each of them appeared on question and answer sessions with Romance Writers of America's Mystery Suspense Chapter Kiss Of Death. I read one book and another until I caught on their various series.
The novellas are quick but thorough books. Don't let the word "novella" fool you. It's a solid plot with twists and turns that earns my 5 stars.

Book #6 of this series and I really loved it! While I'm not a fan of novella's I've really enjoyed this series so far.

There's plenty of action, murder, twists / turns, great characters, quick closure, and I love revisiting with all the characters from all the previous books.

I'm looking forward to the next books this is series.

Would recommend.

Extreme!y simple

A very short and extremely simple story. Not much intrigue or mystery to this one. To be perfectly honest if you don't read the previous 5 books in this series you would be completely lost. I am a fan of the author but truth be told Widow's Island has lost its charm.

A Broken Bone

Murder and deceit

A quick easy read following Tess on the island - with a happy ending.

Great

This whole series has been good. The authors have taken each of the characters and focused on a couple at a time. Good story

But despite the precipitous end of the murder investigation it's still a fun story because it's character driven. There are some very PG elements of romance and the long term friendships found in a relatively isolated small town.

Did not see that coming! Still going wow! Love this series, love this author and love that I am entertained and thought provoked. Easy read

Foster care and homelessness.

Tessa and Logan get called to an explosion, which turns into finding an injured person, a decomposing body, and the remnants of a homeless squatter. The fun and games follow as they dig for the truth and a killer.

I love Logan and Tessa!

Another dark, decaying mystery for Widow's Island, can Tessa find justice for the deceased and ease some of her crippling guilt.
A fantastic novella on Kindle Unlimited, I am looking forward to more visits to Widow's Island.

Well done

Easy reading!

I have enjoyed all this of the widows island series. They are all short quick reads with great plots for all of them. The are a continuing series so I would definitely suggest anyone reading them starts with book 1!

The Widow's Island novellas are captivating and suspenseful reads. A Broken Bone pulls the reader along with Tessa and Logan on the case of a murdered foster child. Melinda Leigh writes a fascinating mystery with a surprising villain. I love how the community comes together to help each other.
The Widow's Island series is fabulous!

Fans of Charlie Holmberg will absolutely love this. It felt very similar to Paper Magician while being something entirely unique. I could not put it down. (Except when I had to take care of my children. How rude of them.)

The magic is intriguing, the characters so well developed, and the plot pulls you right in.

How Charlie continues to write amazing book after amazing book is mind boggling. I'm sure glad she does, though.

The only downside is...waiting for book two. üò≠

In the first of a two-book series, Holmberg introduces us to a young spellbreaker as distinguished from a spellmaker. If you are looking for gritty, rough-edged realistic fantasy, this is probably not the novel for you. Geared for a younger dreamier audience, it gives us a Victorian England filled with all manner of magic spells. Just not my cup of tea.

I have very mixed feelings now I've finished Spellbreaker.

Having seen this come up as a choice on October's Amazon First Reads, it sounded right up my street. Elsie is an illegal spellbreaker, she knows of magic but cannot perform spells, only break them. How do I love Charlie N Holmberg‚Äôs writing‚Ä¶ let me count the ways. Each one of her stories has a strong female lead who has such impeccable morals and a practical head on her shoulders. They are so easy to fall in love with and root for. I was a huge fan of The Paper Magician series, as well as The Will and the Wilds.

She has a way of building a magical world without completely overwhelming you in unnecessary world building. You dive right in with a character who is easy to identify with, and th

A truly remarkable book. I would go as far as to say this is Charlie's next "Paper Magician" series and one fans, myself included, will want more from for years to come.

Ellie is a unregistered Spellbreaker working for a secret society of Robin Hood type vigilantes.

When their world's collide a greater mystery is unveiled. Who can you trust?

Very very good.

WHAT IT'S ABOUT
In Victorian England, there are two kinds of wizards: those rich enough to make spells and the rare few born with the ability to break them.

Another fun book from Charlie! It was just wanted I needed to mentally escape from our current quarantine. Elsie Camden is a girl with a huge secret: an ability to unweave the magic others perform. As an unregistered spellbreaker, that makes her skill illegal and dangerous. An orphan, she balances her days between working for an employer and playing Robin Hood for a secret organization, going on missions to eliminate unjust magic. But then she meets Bacchus Kelsey and that tenuous balance begins to slip, dragging them both into more danger and intrigue than they'd ever thought possible.

'Spellbreaker' is a magical Victorian tale about wizards who cast spells and those who break them. It follows Elsie Camden, a spellbreaker with a mysterious past who works for a secret group of spellbreakers with some suspicious intentions. She encounters Bacchus Kelsey, a dashing wizard who employs Elsie to repair some spells which brings them closer together while also implicating them in some nefarious activities.

Wow! There was nothing about this book that I didn't like. A world of spellmakers and spellbreakers craftily built to draw you in from the first page. Elsie, orphaned as a young girl, currently works for Ogden as an apprentice while also secretly working for the Cowls using her unlicensed spellbreaking ability in the manner of Robin Hood. Magic, mystery, and mayhem abound in a fantasy story like no other!

Nothing is as it seems

I loved the world created in this book. The magic of spellmakers and spellbreakers, a young woman who has been left behind as a six year old and ends up in a workhouse, and a young man looking for a special spell. The major characters had so much depth, and the mysteries just kept adding up.

This book ends in a cliffhanger, so now it's time to look forward to the continuing story.

Enthralling

As always, Holmberg's work is wonderful, beautiful and addictive. Unwinding all the details of the tale and the players was a very interesting venture. I can highly recommend any and all of Holmberg's work, but this book is a very different and interesting take on a magical society. It's so different from Paper Magician, but similar in other ways. If you enjoyed Paper Magician, this is definitely worth a read.

As always, Holmberg did not disappoint with the rich world building and new set of magical mechanics.

I was pleasantly surprised by the small nods to diversity (characters of the lgbt community) throughout the novel that are usually completely absent from the period fantasy genre. Hopefully in the next novel, these will be more than just nods and subtle winks.

The story itself was filled with laughs, excitement and intrigue. Cannot wait for another.

Not buying Book 2!

I really like all of Charlie Holmberg's books! One of my favorite murder mystery subgenres is the ‚Äòlocked room mystery‚Äô. (4.5 Stars) Ruth Ware gives a modern twist to a classic Christie-inspired mystery in her latest thriller, ONE BY ONE. Executives of a hot up and coming tech firm called Snoop head to a remote chalet high in the Alps for a company retreat. This dream getaway of skiing, great food, and breathtaking views takes a tragic turn when an avalanche hits, trapping their party in a half-buried chalet. Their situation becomes more terrifying when guests disappear or are found dead, picked off one by one. Bu

Actual rating 4.5/5 stars.

Erin and Danny reside and work in one of these chalets and are preparing for an influx of new arrivals. The ten figures who step through their doors all work for the trending app, Snoop. Ho hum, I‚Äôm glad I‚Äôm done.

Now we are ten.

Now we are eight.
The words chant inside my head, a kind of gruesome countdown, edging closer to zero, one by one.

I bounced back and forth between 3 and 4 stars. I actually liked the story... But it was such a long slow burn that I found myself getting bored a lot. The setting was fabulously spooky... LOVED the setting. The large volume of characters were relatively easy to keep straight, but because there were so many there wasn‚Äôt much character development on most of them. Overall, the setting of the book was my favorite part... it wasn‚Äôt an awful book, just a bit too slow for me.

Just the thing to read when you need switch-off entertainment that is gripping but unchallenging. The spotify-alike app company gives a contemporary edge updating the Agatha Christie plot. Ware cleverly twists her model and also gives her reveal early enough to really ramp up the tension in the final 25%. Some of the characterization is thin with people barely being more than names and what Erin does with a broken ankle makes her superwoman! Still, it's worth just going with the flow - a fun, on

One by One is a modern take on a classic locked room mystery with some major Agatha Christie vibe. I must admit I love a good mystery so my expectations are always high.

A book centres around a group of people trapped in the remote chalet in French Alps when the avalanche strikes down. But that‚Äôs not their only concern - soon they start dying ‚Äúone by one‚Äù and it becomes clear one of them is a killer.

A locked room mystery theme was done many times before but what makes this novel different is an

A wildly successful but small new tech company is at a crossroads. Will they sell or go public? The eight coworkers decide to go on a ski retreat, counting on a weekend of bonding and play at a beautiful, isolated chalet to help them come to an agreement. But business discussions go south quickly and tensions are clearly running high. When one group member doesn‚Äôt make it back from her black diamond run, suddenly everyone‚Äôs a suspect. After an avalanche traps everyone in the cabin, none of the r
Enjoyed this one. However, I think it was fairly obvious who was the culprit right from the start. Srill, it was an enjoyable read!

If you took An Unwanted Guest (Shari Lapena), The Hunting Party, The Guest List (Lucy Foley) and In a Dark Dark Wood, and mixed them all up into one book, the result might be One by One. It was compulsively readable but felt very familiar. If you‚Äôre a fan of the books listed above, you‚Äôd like this one too. A good one for a rainy long weekend.

Very enjoyable mystery--kept me turning the pages to find out how the author was going to wrap it up.
One of the downsides to being older than dirt is that it is very, very difficult for a young writer to surprise or shock you with the actual 'who' in a 'whodunnit'. The 'how' and 'why' are often a surprise, though. Such was the case with this clever tale from Ms Ware.

So

"I used to think that the present determined the future. That if I worked hard and long, I'd get the things I wanted. The job, the apartment, the life. That the future was simply a mound of clay waiting to be told by the present what form to take. But that isn't true . . . " -- Dannie Kohan, on page 225

It's no secret I love mindbending books that play with the concept of time. As soon as I read the blurb for this one, I knew I would be bumping it to the top of my to be read list. I'm so glad I did because this book was very nearly perfect and not what I was expecting at all.

This book was fantastic. I would recommend not reading the book blurb right before reading this book. As it gives away a lot of the story IMO.

The narrator is Dannie (1st person POV). The story is set in NYC. She is a very ambitious lawyer. The story starts in December 2020 (and moves forward until we reach five years later).

There is romance in this book. However to me this was not the main focus of the

4 Friendship Stars

This novel is a romance, but I think it is much more the story of a lifelong friendship between Dannie and Bella. Friends since they were seven, the two of them approach life very differently, but have a strong bond of friendship. Dannie has her life completely mapped out, career, love life, etc. while Bella is much more spontaneous.

Early in the book, Dannie has a key job interview and important relationship milestone all locked down on her timing. That night, though, she dream

I cried! What the hell? My first five star book for this year gave me emotions. This book may involved a trope I‚Äôm not really a fan of but surprisingly I didn‚Äôt really much care. The writing was easy. You can just like fly through it. To be petty, I think my only issue is that I was mislead from the blurb? Generally, the blurb(not the one in goodreads) says that the main character wakes up five years later and everything was just different. I think book is more than that or quite different from

What if you suddenly woke up five years in the future and didn't recognise yourself?

28-year-old Dannie Cohan is obsessively committed to achieving her five-year plan. And everything is on schedule ‚Äì December 15th, 2020 sees her nailing an interview for a top law firm, and by the end of the night engaged to her live-in boyfriend of two years, David.8

But when she falls asleep, she awakens at 10:59pm in an unfamiliar apartment, next to a strange man who clearly lives there with her, wearing a diffe
All thanks to this book now I know another trope that I dislike.

Speaking of fate, I noticed that when I pick up two books to read (one e-book, and one physical book) alternately, for some reason there usually seems something similar between them. Like two weeks ago, I decided to read an e-book of Things You Save in a Fire and a physical copy of The First Time She Drowned and both main characters' name is Cassie.

Last week when I picked an e-copy of In Five Years, I also chose Something Like Fate and both stories are about the main characters having an inexpli

This novel was heartbreakingly beautiful. It's a story that makes you think both existentially and theologically and is also a story about love but not solely the romantic kind.

From the beginning to the end, everything was connected within the story and tied together so neatly that made it even more heartbreaking at the end.

This novel reminds you about the fragility of life and relationships. It's also a reminder on the importance of pursuing a passionate love and not settling on one of conven

4 Stars!
(ARC provided by Atria Books)



Dannie Kohan is a young, ambitious, Manhattan corporate lawyer who is extremely passionate about her job. She‚Äôs worked hard to get to where she is, and is determined to succeed. Everything in her life is planned and predictable. She stays in her comfort zone, and is a type A personality. She thinks she has everything figured out, and is on track to soon being engaged and landing her dream job at the top firm in the city. She has an interview for a job tha

Where do you see yourself in a year? Five years? The rest of your life? There are planners like me and then there are the free spirits. I was taught to have a plan for my day. Planners make the most of their time and time is a valuable commodity.
The more you plan ahead, the less time you waste but do you feel everything and experience all of life‚Äôs riches if you are always planning.
Manhattan lawyer, Danni Cohan, is a type A personality. A planners role model. Daily and future planner extraordina

Dannie has a plan for her life, and she has been following that plan to a T. She and David seem to be perfect for each other as he fits right into her life and she seems to do the same within his. This is one of those relationships that aren't really tested with conflict, compromise and wanting different things. They have found the perfect match because they both want the same exact things out of life. Is that enough though, is that the way it's supposed to work?

Dannie goes to an interview for

Song/s the book brought to mind: Wonderwall by Oasis

Well thank you to Rebecca Serle for completely breaking my heart with In Five Years. It was not at all what I expected, and you better be prepared to cry your eyes out, I sure did!

Don't you love when a book completely surprises you in a good way? I sure do, and that's what In Five Years did to me. It may be a short book at 250 pages, but it is bursting with heart and will give you ALL the feels. Friendship, heartbreak, loss, hope, love - it's a

I liked In Five Years way more than I expected ‚Äî especially as the story develops. Dannie is a serious type A. She‚Äôs a corporate lawyer in New York City and she happily calibrates every minute of her day. She has a five year plan that includes being a partner at her firm and marrying her corporate finance boyfriend. The only part of her life that is a bit less controlled is her strong bond with her childhood friend Bella. Then a dream or premonition shakes her up ‚Äî she sees herself in 2015 with

In Five Years was the kind of book that snuck up on me in the best kind of way and overwhelmed me with its beautiful writing and storyline in a manner I did not expect. When Dannie somehow ends up five years in the future with a man who is definitely not her fiance, she doesn't think a ton of it - until back in present day, she meets her best friends new boyfriend - the man from the future.

IFY will unfold in a way that you will not expect (at least I definitely did not) and if you are anything l

My best friend suggested this one to me if I wanted a good cry, considering this past weekend her wedding was cancelled thanks to Covid-19, I think a good cry was in order. My goodness was she right! I cried so much in this one.

You have to go in to this one blind. It‚Äôs a love story but definitely not what you think. I loved the direction this one took and it was such an important story to tell.

Disclaimer, I hated the ending and have decided to just pretend that part didn‚Äôt happen.

Seriously go i

Top Five Reasons You Should Read In Five Years:

1. A thought provoking read that will make you question all the what ifs in life.

2. Relatable characters you can't help connecting with.

3. Rich in detail and a plot line we can all relate to.

4. A setting that will make your heart pitter patter at.

5. Beautiful writing that draws you right into the story and makes you think about it long after you've put it down.

My heart hurts! I loved it!

‚ÄúYou mistake love. You think it has to have a future in order to matter, but it doesn‚Äôt. It‚Äôs the only thing that does not need to become at all. It matters only insofar as it exists. Here. Now. Love doesn‚Äôt require a future.‚Äù

I liked all the characters, but I'm still not sure if I like the main idea of the plot, or how I would feel in this situation.
It was okay, but quite forgettable on the long run. Still recommend this if you need something fluffy and easy right now.
